data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Let dds_read/dds_take do real loans

With this commit, dds_read/dds_take and all variants now return pointers
to shared copies of data if this is possible (which it not always is).
As a consequence, modifying the contents of the loans will have possibly
disastrous effects, whereas before one could away with it.

If a private copy is required, the application must now allocate the
memory itself (if there are any embedded pointers, those must be null
pointers).  One must now do:

    void *sampleptr = dds_alloc (sizeof (T));
    dds_take (reader, &sampleptr, sampleinfo, 1, 1);
    ...
    dds_sample_free (sampleptr, &T_desc, DDS_FREE_ALL);

to get a private copy in heap-allocated memory. (Obviously, other
allocation/freeing routines are ok as well.)

This is a breaking change and it has not been done lightly.  The
considerations are:

- This really only breaks applications that modify "loaned" memory,
  which has always been dodgy behaviour at best, and is assumed to be
  extremely rare in application code.

- The majority of applications will now benefit from zero-copy behaviour
  where it is supported, and without having to worry about which API
  function is the appropriate one to use.

- It reduces the API surface.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Test read/read_wl produce private/shared copies

Read (non-_wl) must always result in private copies (as per the
documentation), so that is easy to check.

Read-with-loan may or may not return shared copies, and which of the two
happens is highly implementation dependent, both of Cyclone's core and
of a PSMX plugin. This test checks it against current behaviour, in
particular verifying zero-copy and shared loans of self-contained data
types in combination with Iceoryx.

data.author: eboasson
data.message:
Always respect SPDPInterval setting (#1829)

* Always respect SPDPInterval setting

The code used to silently limit the SPDP interval to approximately 80%
of the lease duration for addressing some interoperability issues at
some point in the past.  That meant that even in a Cyclone-only system
it would be impossible to raise the interval beyond this limit.

This extends the valid values with the special value "default" in which
case it does exactly the same as it used to do if the setting was left
at the default (30s).  With this change, if it is set to a numerical
value, that specified interval is respected without taking the lease
duration into consideration.

That means that a configuration in which the SPDP interval was set to
some value greater than 80% of the lease duration, the rate now goes
down.  In all other cases, the behaviour is unchanged.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

* Move and reword comment

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

---------

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Phil
data.message:
Introduce ddsrt_allocation_ops and ddsrt_set_allocators (#1821)

* Introduce ddsrt_allocation_ops and ddsrt_set_allocators

This commit introduces the `ddsrt_allocation_ops_t` struct, which
encapsulates memory allocation function pointers (malloc, calloc,
realloc, free). Additionally the user may change these from the default
functions of `stdlib` with the new function `ddsrt_set_allocators`.

The new struct makes it easier to change allocation
strategies.

Changes:
- Added `ddsrt_allocation_ops_t` struct
- Added `ddsrt_set_allocators(ddsrt_allocation_ops)`
- Added `static ddsrt_allocator`, with default members from `stdlib`
- Changed `stdlib` allocator calls to use `ddsrt_allocator.{function}` etc.

CP-221

* Add `ddsrt_set_allocator` to symbol_export

CP-221

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Reject NaN in uf_int64_unit

sscanf will happily parse a "nan" as a floating-point input, resulting
in an attempt at converting a NaN into an integer instead of rejecting
it outright.

That NaN then was manipulated and ended up in a range check:

  if (v_dbl_abs_scaled >= (double) INT64_MAX)

but because all comparisons involving a NaN evaluate as false, it passes
this check and, at least on some platforms, causes undefined behaviour
by trying to evaluate -INT64_MIN.

This commit inverts the sense of the check.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Avoid qsort_r because of older MUSL versions

There was only place where it is used, that is in the IDL compiler, to
sort a vector of strings. By using qsort_r, the compare function
supplied to the "sort vector" operation could operate on elements, with
the dereferencing step done inside the vector implementation, which is
much nicer than requiring the supplied compare function to do that
dereference.

Unfortunately, qsort_r is not sufficiently widely supported.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Marcel Jordense
data.message:
Update raweth to DDS-TSN spec with vlan-tagging

This updates the "raweth" locators to conform to the format specified in
the DDS over TSN spec, including the support for VLAN tagging.

Cyclone's heritage as an implementation originally built for the UDP PSM
is a bit in the way here, as the core code takes care of some of the
port number calculations that are really specific to the UDP PSM.
Rather than reworking it to move all of this into the UDP-specific code,
it splits the "port" field of the locator into some arbitrary mixture of
a "port" and "aux" field, both mapped into the 32 bits and with
transport-dependent division.

For UDP this combined field is all port and no aux (though the port is
constrained to 16 bits), for Ethernet it is a 16-bits port and a 16-bits
"aux" field that encodes the VLAN id and priority as spec'd.  It is not
elegant, but it is a less invasive change and not hard to undo when
needed.

VLAN id and priority are encoded in the Ethernet address strings by
appending .VLANID.PRIORITY to the standard MAC address, with both
defaulting to 0.

To transmit the data, the ethernet header needs to be part of the iovecs
passed to sendmsg(), and room must be made available.  That is done by
replacing the old niov/iov pair in ddsi_conn_write() with a new
ddsi_tran_write_msgfrags_t structure that combines the two and also
contains some space immediately preceding the iov array for use by the
transport.  This allows the raweth code to prepend the header with
having to make a copy.

Signed-off-by: Marcel Jordense <marcel@zettascale.tech>
Co-authored-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Fix cdrstream bug for union types (#1800)

* Fix cdrstream bug for union types

When using a sample for deserialization of CDR for a type that
has a union, the sample data for the union was cleared before
deserialization (indicated by the DDS_TOPIC_CONTAINS_UNION). In
case the union type is used for an external or mutable member,
this could lead to reading uninitialize sample data when re-using
allocated sample data over multiple reads. E.g. in this data type:

@final @nested
union u switch(octet) {
    case 1:
        // sequence<string>  u1;
        sequence<string<3> >  u1;
    default:
        string d;
};

@mutable
struct s {
    u f1;
};

This commit fixes the issue by introducing a sample-data-state
parameter in the read (deserialize) functions in cdrstream, and
ensures that sample data is only read when the data state is
'initialized'. In case of switching cases for a union, the state
for the sample data in that context is set to 'uninitialized',
so that the deserializer doesn't read the data (e.g. to check if
a pointer needs to be released) for nested types; in that case it
will just allocate the memory and assume releasing it is not
required.

The DDS_TOPIC_CONTAINS_UNION is not used anymore and removed from
the IDLC generator. It is only kept in dds_opcodes.h for backward
compatibility.

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis@zettascale.tech>

* Bugfix in stream_write_key_impl

While serializing, the serializer shouldn't allocate memory for an
external field (and because addr typically is non-null here, the
call to dds_stream_alloc_external was effectively a de-reference
of addr). Replaced this with just the dereference.

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis@zettascale.tech>

* Delete dead code in dds_stream_reuse_string_bound

It correctly never allocated because the "alloc" flag was always false,
and it should never do so either. That means the "allocator" and
"sample_state" arguments are superfluous as well.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

* Delete outdated and misleading comment

We no longer need initialize memory immediately after allocating an
external member when deserializing, and so the comment that we must
initialize is no outdated and now misleading.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

* cdrstream: tweak empty string handling

We generally have to allocate memory for a string because finding out
the string length in C involves scanning the memory and because we don't
know how much additional memory was allocated for whatever is stored in
the sample.

The case of deserializing an empty string is slightly different: we can
easily check if the sample we're updating already contained an empty
string. It seems a reasonable assumption that optimizing this case is
worth the effort.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

* Refactor sequence buffer allocations

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

---------

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis@zettascale.tech>
Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>
Co-authored-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: reicheratwork
data.message:
Separated idl to c code generator off into own library (#1752)

* Separated idl to c code generator off into own library

This required the generation of extra export headers in addition

Changed function parameter names to prevent any possible shadowing

Moved and renamed libidlc files to their own folder
Moved and renamed generator_common files to their own folder
Moved idlc files to their own folder

* Merged idlc_common library into idl

After a suggestion from @eboasson moved the functions (name
generation, typeinfo blobs) which will be shared between different
language bindings (C, C++, python, ...) into the idl library
This made the idl_common library superfluous, so that was deleted

Renamed idlcs plugin.* files to generator.* to keep it compatible
with all other language bindings.
The contents of these files was previously split between other files
and the generator file was removed, by doing this other bindings
(C++/python/???) should not require any modifications.

* Fix declaration/definition mismatch

* Clean up IDLC header guards

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

---------

data.message:
Add ENABLE_TYPELIB build option

This adds the ENABLE_TYPELIB build option (default is ON) that controls
including the type library (which stores the type meta-data for types
used in local entities and in discovered proxy entities). The
ENABLE_TYPELIB also controls the availability of the type-builder (to
construct the type meta-data used by the serialized, e.g. used from the
Python API) and the dynamic type API.

Most of the functionality that can be disabled/enabled with this option
was previously controlled by the ENABLE_TYPE_DISCOVERY build option.
That option is also still available, but now only controls the inclusion
of the type lookup functionality (that allows resolving type meta-data for
types from discovery endpoints or topics).

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Fix field order in key-only sample serialization

Use definition order for key field order in serialized key-only sample,
and use the extensibility of the original type for key serialization.
This commit update the CDR stream serializer for this, and changes the
IDL compiler and dynamic type builder to include the keys in definition
order. The sort-order (3rd column) in the key list of the topic descriptor
reflects the member-ID order of the key fields, which is used in
serialization of the key for calculating the key hash.

The calculation of the key flags is moved to the CDR stream
serializer and is done runtime, so that this can be used for both
IDLC and type builder generated descriptors.

generation_rank in the dds_sample_info_t that is passed to the collector

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Add dds_read/take_with_collector API and refactor

This commit adds a new pair of API functions:

* dds_read_with_collector
* dds_take_with_collector

The key difference with all the other read/take functions is that this
pair takes a callback function as an argument, to be called for each
sample matched by the conditions given in the other arguments.

The RHC interface has been updated to make this the only model for
reading/taking data.  Consequently, the regular read/take has been
reworked and readcdr/takecdr are now simply wrappers around the new API
functions.  Some of the common code in setting up read/take variants is
now factored out into separate functions.

This also eliminates the abomination that was the "lock samples"
operation and the magic value for the maximum number of samples to read
to prevent locking.  This therefore also fixes some odd issues caused by
the magic number and elimates the conditional lock/unconditional unlock
in the RHC that was one of the internal consequences of the abomination.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.message:
Remove incorrect assert in serdata_pserop_fix

It is incorrect to assert that payload should be at least 16 bytes large
in for the "pserop" sertype.  That condition is only valid if the topic
is keyed, because it only supports keys that are exactly 16 bytes large.

Instead, for an unkeyed topic, anything size is plausible and it is the
deserializer that rejects malformed input.

This commit also adds some tests for some variations on the participant
message data theme, including one that triggers the assertion.  in
addition there is a bit of additional checking in constructing a new
sertype_pserop.

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
IDLC: reject arrays of 0 elements

IDL 4.2 7.4.1.4.4.5 requires that the array size is a positive int,
XTypes 1.3 7.3.1.6 states that arrays are fully compatible with the IDL
constructs of the same names, so 0 must be rejected.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Reject 0-dimensional arrays and empty arrays

IDL 4.2 7.4.1.4.4.5 requires that the array size is a positive int and
makes it syntactically impossible to construct 0-dimensional arrays.

XTypes 1.3 7.3.1.6 states that arrays are fully compatible with the IDL
constructs of the same names.

Therefore, both arrays with an empty sequence of bounds and arrays with
a bound of 0 in some dimension are illegal and must be rejected by the
type validation code.

Note that the XTypes 1.3 7.2.2.4.3 spec states more generally that
array, sequence, string and map bounds must be either positive or
"unbounded".  It then leaves the encoding for "unbounded" in type
objects undefined, but in practice (and certainly in Cyclone) it is
mapped to 0.  Therefore strings, sequences and maps correctly allow a
bound of 0.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Dynamic type API fixes

This fixes two issues in dynamic type construction:

- The name-hash for aggregated type members was not set, which resulted
  in incorrect minimal DDSI types when creating a type-info object.

- The element flags for collection types were not set, but should get
  the default value TRY_CONSTRUCT_DISCARD, so that the generated DDSI
  types match with the types generated using IDLC

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis@zettascale.tech>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Fix type-info and type-map construction in dynamic type API

This fixes a number of issues in the construction of type-info
and type-map objects in the type library, related to the dynamic
type API:

- dds_dynamic_type_t now has a pointer to both the complete and the
  minimal DDSI type, so that refcounting for the minimal types can
  also be done correctly. Minimal types are inserted in the type library
  when registering a dynamic type, when the type-info object is created.
  When the minimal DDSI type pointer is not NULL, the refcount for the
  minimal top-level DDSI type for a dynamic type is also updated when
  updating the dynamic type refcount in the same way the complete type's
  refc is updated.

- The unused function ddsi_type_pair_minimal_info is removed; a type-
  info object can only be fully generated from a complete DDSI type.
  ddsi_type_pair_complete_info is renamed to ddsi_type_pair_get_typeinfo.

- The dynamic type implementation did not hold the typelib lock in
  certain cases; this is fixed in this commit. Additionally, locking is
  added in ddsi_type_get_typeinfo_ser, ddsi_type_get_typemap_ser
  and ddsi_type_pair_get_typeinfo

- Getting the list of dependent types for type-info and type-map
  construction was not taking the element type of plain-collection
  types into account and not handling nested hashed types correctly.
  This commit has a refactored implementation for both that resolves
  these issues. For getting the type-map, the entries are now also
  de-duplicated.

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis@zettascale.tech>

according to MISRA Appendix D only consists of the `char` type. For
context `unsigned char` is within the essentially unsigned category and
not the essentially character category.

data.author: NoxPardalis
data.message:
Address MISRA rule 3.1 violations across Cyclone (#1662)

* [CP-277] Address MISRA rule 3.1 violations across Cyclone

This resolves the issue of `//` within `/*...*/` comments. These
typically feature within the URLs present in the copyright blurbs
and are allowed within comments starting with a `//` but not the
`/*...*/` style comments. This is applied across all `.c`, `.h`, and
`.idl` files and also results in the following files being regenerated:

- docs/manual/config/config_file_reference.rst
- docs/manual/options.md
- etc/cyclonedds.rnc
- etc/cyclonedds.xsd
- src/core/ddsi/defconfig.c

* [CP-277] Catch last two violations of MISRA 3.1 in copyright blurbs

* [CP-277] Fix violations of MISRA Rule 3.1 in all other comments

* [CP-277] Apply review fix for context being removed from comment on `ddsi_get_participant_builtin_topic_data`

Was too over-zealous with trimming the comment in the `/* ... */` -> `//`
changeover.

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Dynamic type API: set TRY_CONSTRUCT to DISCARD

Struct and union members must have a valid setting for TRY_CONSTRUCT,
this sets the default value to DISCARD, in line with the XTypes
specification.

Before both the TRY_CONSTRUCT1 and TRY_CONSTRUCT2 flags were clear, and
so one would expect it to have been rejected by the type object
validation, except we are still accepting that value for backwards
compatibility with the 0.9 release.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: eboasson
data.message:
Add a "writer batching" QoS (#1660)

* Add a "writer batching" QoS

This adds a QoS setting to control whether or not a writer does batching
without any (possible) dependency on asynchronous publications.
Batching means small samples get combined in a single RTPS message,
improving performance.

This message only gets sent automatically when it is full, and if it is
important that the preceding samples are actually sent, then the
application code must explicitly flush the batch by call `dds_flush`.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

* Better documentation

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

---------

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Fix serdata_default getting key from Iceoryx chunk

dds_serdata_default (so the default sample implementation used only by
the C binding) always stores the serialized key in native XCDR2 format,
but this was broken for Iceoryx chunks.

For the case of a local write, the code assumed that the iox chunk
contains a "raw sample" rather than a serialized sample.  This was
correct until 8845a81ce77f78df2816a74b01cf89686f96581d (pr #1031)
changed that.

The typical failure mode (but not the only one) is a crash if the key
contains a string and if the data is volatile and all subscribers are
addressed via Iceoryx.  In practice this turns out to have been rare
enough that no-one noticed it until now.

For the case of data coming in over Iceoryx, there was a confusion
between the DDSI keyhash and the key representation in
serdata_default (the former is the big-endian serialisation of the key
or the MD5 hash thereof; the latter is always native-endianness XCDR2
serialisation of the key and so resistant to collision attacks).

The typical failure mode here is one of instance confusion: either
mapping to different key values to the same instance, or mapping what
really is the same key value to different instances.

This commit always extracts the key from the actual data in the Iceoryx
chunk.  In the case of a local write, we know we have the sample in
memory somwhere, even if the chunk contains the serialized
representation.  Nonetheless, here it extracts the key from the
serialized form because at the point where we need to do it, we do not
have a pointer to the original sample and changing the interface for
this rare case is not worth it at this point in time.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Chris Lalancette
data.message:
Fix a warning when building in release mode.

When building the 0.10.x branch in release mode, we
are seeing the following warning:

In function ‘dds_serdata_builtin_from_topic_definition’,
    inlined from ‘dds__builtin_make_sample_topic_impl’ at ros2_rolling/src/eclipse-cyclonedds/cyclonedds/src/core/ddsc/src/dds_builtin.c:302:34:
ros2_rolling/src/eclipse-cyclonedds/cyclonedds/src/core/ddsc/src/dds_serdata_builtintopic.c:468:3: warning: writing 16 bytes into a region of size 0 [-Wstringop-overflow=]
  468 |   memcpy (&d->common.key.raw, key, sizeof (d->common.key.raw));

I believe what is happening here is that the compiler is
finding a path through the code where serdata_builtin_new()
can allocate and return a struct of 0 size.  That can
theoretically happen if the tp->entity_kind is not one
of the known types when serdata_builtin_new() is called.
Given that this is an exceptional situation, detect this
and abort().  Note that we use abort() and not assert()
here as the latter will be compiled out in release builds.

While we are in here, change the syntax of the memcpy command
as well.  While the previous version wasn't wrong, this one
makes it much more clear that we are copying the key bytes
from one structure to another.  If this part is objectionable,
it can be dropped.

Signed-off-by: Chris Lalancette <clalancette@openrobotics.org>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Fix typebuilder max key size for unbounded strings

An unbounded string key field was treated as sizeof(char*) in computing
the maximum serialized key size (in dynamically constructed serializer
operations for the C binding), rather than as infinity.  If this
computed maximum is no more than some fixed size, then (for the C
binding):

* Samples rely on a pre-allocated buffer for storing the serialized key,
  and handling a key for which the serialised form is actually longer will
  result in trying to reallocate a non-malloc'd buffer;

* The decisions whether the DDSI keyhash is the serialised key or the
  MD5 of it will be taken incorrectly.  (Cyclone doesn't really use them,
  but needs to support them regardless.)

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
plist (de)serialization vs short enums and packing

The (gcc) option -fshort-enums causes the enumerated types used in the
discovery information to become char-sized things instead of int-sized
things. This breaks the plist serializer in really bad ways.

Additionally, there are some platforms where _Alignof returns a larger
alignment than what the compiler uses as alignment of a struct
member (without having used #pragma pack or similar). This also breaks
the plist serializer in really bad ways.

This commit attempts to address these issues by serialising an enum
using a enum type that also fits in 1 byte, and by computing the
alignment of a struct member via offsetof in the plist handling.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Rework (timed) event queue scheduling a bit

This moves the "schedule time rounding" into the sleeping a bit longer
in ddsrt_cond_waitfor, which should be a slightly cheaper approximation
of the old behaviour that's close-enough for a probably never-used
feature.

It also changes the event handling loop to not re-read the clock on
every processed event.  This makes the timestamp passed into the handler
further behind, but it also means the inner loop handling timed events
will stop earlier, and so starvation of non-timed events is less likely
to occur.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Move "entityid" events out of ddsi_xevent

They really are no more than conditional queueing of a particular
message, and that is all intimately tied to proxy endpoints and the
matching thereof. Constructing the message in the proxy endpoint code
and simply queueing it is arguably cleaner, and it removes all
dependencies on (proxy) entity implementation details from the event
queue.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Replace special-cased timed events by callbacks

This necessitates some changes:

* Extending the callbacks with an "xpack" parameter that was available
  to the special-cased functions for sending data out from a handler.

* Making synchronisation between execution of the callback and deleting
  the event optional, to not introduce (unnecessary) blocking where it
  wasn't there before.

* Changing the closure argument to a blob that is copied into the event,
  rather than an arbitrary pointer.  The problem is a need to avoid
  races with the garbage collector which makes it impossible to store
  the pointer to an entity without introducing additional stages in the
  deletion process.  This in turn forces an additional indirection in
  the "old" callbacks.

* The internal functions heavily relied on the availability of a "gv"
  pointer, this could easily be emulated via the closure argument, but it
  seems to make more sense to pass it as an argument.

This allows moving a lot of handler code to more reasonable places,
which in turn made "ddsi_discovery" explode too messy to survive without
splitting it.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Gracefully handle insane deadline settings

This fixes a number of issues in handling extremely short and extremely
long deadline durations:

* a divide-by-zero issue in the deadline handling when the
  deadline duration is set to zero

* spinning inside the loops processing all expired deadlines when the
  deadline is so short that it expires earlier than the processing
  completes

* a potential overflow in case of extremely short or extremely long
  deadlines

* rate-limits the deadline notification callbacks for periodic
  deadlines

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Dynamic Type API

This introduces the implementation of the Dynamic Language binding
as defined in section 7.5.2 of the DDS XTypes specification. The API
in this implementation is roughly following the API as described in
the specification, but different choices where made at some points
(also because the approach in the spec is aimed at object oriented
languages).

This commit contains the Dynamic Type part of the dynamic language
binding, not the Dynamic Data part (which may be added later). The
type introspection part is also left out in this initial version.

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis@zettascale.tech>

data.author: Dennis Potman

This adds support for the int8 and uint8 type kinds in the IDL
compiler and the type library and xtypes wrapper. The IDL file
describing the type object that is provided by the OMG spec was
not updated for these missing type kinds, which was fixed in the
spec text (including the IDL that is included in the spec as
annex). See also https://issues.omg.org/issues/DDSXTY14-52

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Take partitions into account in Iceoryx

The mapping of readers/writers to Iceoryx failed to take the partition
QoS into consideration, and so allow data from a writer using partition
A to arrive at a reader using partition B.

This changes the logic to:

* not use Iceoryx for any complicated cases, that is: where there is
  more than one partition or a wildcard is involved; and

* extends the "topic" name in Iceoryx to include the (now
  known-to-be-simple) partition name

This eliminates the crosstalk and hopefully is flexible enough to not
avoid using Iceoryx in important cases.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Test dds_writecdr with mismatching sertype

If one calls dds_writecdr on a writer with sertype A passing a
ddsi_serdata from sertype B, a new serdata of type A is constructed
using the serialised representation.  This is a rather unusual path,
which generally means a specific test is useful.

This test verifies that the change in reference counts of these objects
matches the expectation.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: reicheratwork
data.message:
Implement time-based filter functionality (#1506)

* Implement time-based filter functionality

The QoSPolicy minimum_separation now does filtering of samples on
the reader side.
Samples received within the minimum_separation window will not be
put into the reader history cache, but instead be treated as being
lost.
Added unittests to test this new functionality

Signed-off-by: Martijn Reicher <martijn.reicher@zettascale.tech>

* Fixes due to GitHub comments

Added fixes due to GitHub comments
- assert checks function result in temporary variable, not the
result of the call directly
- fixed function signatures by making empty function parameter
lists void
- added unittests for invalid timestamps

Signed-off-by: Martijn Reicher <martijn.reicher@zettascale.tech>

* Correct handling of missing source timestamps

Improved time-based filter where invalid (missing) source timestamps
are now handled properly.
An invalid timestamp, either on the incoming or stored sample will
no longer cause a filtering comparison, only a writer comparison.

Signed-off-by: Martijn Reicher <martijn.reicher@zettascale.tech>

* Improved time based filter test cases

- added unique topic names
- additional checks for null pointers
- removed variables only used as function parameters as superfluous
- correct cleanup of created entities

Signed-off-by: Martijn Reicher <martijn.reicher@zettascale.tech>

* Further improvements to time based filter

Time based filter now also applies even if ordering is not just
BY_SOURCE_TIMESTAMP

Signed-off-by: Martijn Reicher <martijn.reicher@zettascale.tech>

---------

Signed-off-by: Martijn Reicher <martijn.reicher@zettascale.tech>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Add OSS fuzzer test for type object validation (#1558)

* Add oss-fuzz test for type object validation.

To get to the point where a type object can be validated, the
input for this test is a typemap that contains a set of type objects.
So this also tests the deserialization of typemap (which includes
deserialization of its embedded type objects).

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis@zettascale.tech>

* Add check for none-typeid in fuzzer test

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis@zettascale.tech>

* Reduce max_len setting for type object fuzzer test (max seed corpus length is 4250b, so a limit of 65536 should be enough)

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis@zettascale.tech>

data.author: Martijn Reicher
data.message:
Fix deadline updates "overwriting" outstanding deadlines

Updates to instances with an expired, but not yet processed deadline
will push back the deadline and hereby "overwriting" the deadline
that has expired
This is fixed by keeping track of the last time the deadline was
triggered, and storing "additional" expiries that happen before the
timed event thread processes the deadline entry

Signed-off-by: Martijn Reicher <martijn.reicher@zettascale.tech>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Do not inherit irrelevant topic QoS in rd/wr

The set of topic QoS is an extended subset of the reader QoS (e.g., the
"lifespan" QoS). Allowing those that are irrelevant to the reader to end
up in the reader's QoS object means it shows up as a difference with the
default QoS settings and causes it to be published in the endpoint
discovery data.

As the topic QoS object is deliberately left sparse, this only happens
when the application explicitly sets a QoS on the topic that is not
relevant to the reader. For example, setting the lifespan in the topic
QoS -- and even explicitly setting it to the default value -- causes
this.

The impact is very low because the recipients of the endpoint discovery
data ignore irrelevant (but otherwise valid) QoS values.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Unreliable readers are always "in sync" with pwr

The "in sync" vs "out sync" exists to handle retrieving with historical
data and determining when the "wait for historical data" operation can
return, and to handle cases where a reader deliberately falls behind a
writer because of resource limits.

Neither case exists for unreliable (a.k.a. best-effort) readers. So
arguably, all unreliable readers should always state they are "in sync".

The difference is negligible in the case of *unreliable* remote writers,
but not in the case of *reliable* remote writers. In the latter it can
cause message loss.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: James Pace
data.message:
Add fix suggested in sros2 bug report.

As stated in: https://github.com/OpenDDS/OpenDDS/pull/3992#issue-1548228907

"Implement the suggestion in ros2/sros2#282.
Specifically, use PKCS7_NOINTERN to not accept any signatures in the signed document.
This, in turn, requires the use of the certs parameter to PKCS7_verify.
PKCS7_NOVERIFY is used since the permissions CA certificate will not be chain verified."

Fixes: https://github.com/eclipse-cyclonedds/cyclonedds/issues/1546
Related to: https://github.com/ros2/sros2/issues/282

Signed-off-by: James Pace <jpace121@gmail.com>

Documentation edits to the Getting Started Section (#1510)

* Documentation edits to the Getting Started Section

I've made changes to the Installation and Benchmarking sections. I've also split these sections into separate files.

* Updated with review comments

As this was a large topic, with multiple sections, I split it into several files.

Co-authored-by: Phil <25635927+poetinger@users.noreply.github.com>

* Edits to the Network configuration page

I've separated the Network configuration section into its own page.

In addition, I've updated the log on the Getting started page so that it is smaller, and has a white background.

I've also started to add index and glossary entries. The definitions for  the glossary items need to be defined - see https://github.com/orgs/ZettaScaleLabs/projects/5/views/2?visibleFields=%5B%22Title%22%2C23825276%2C%22Assignees%22%2C%22Status%22%5D

* Edits to the Data path configuration

In addition to the edits, I have put all the external html links into a separate file. Hopefully, this will make it easier to check for broken or superseded links.

* Edits to the Network partition configuration

This includes updates to cross-references, index and glossary

* Edits to the Examples pages

* Edits to the Security pages

I've split the security pages into separate files so that they appear in the left-hand TOC

* Further edits to the Configuration pages

I've separated the Network configuration into separate topics.

* Edits to the Shared memory section

I've split the Shared memory page into separate files and moved it to a Shared memory folder. I've also updated the Getting started logo to a scalable svg.

* Updated in response to review comments

Mostly, minor changes to capitalisation. Also some fixes to the Network configuration pages

* Added a introduction section and merged HelloWorld tutorials into a single tutorial

I've added a top-level section that has much the same information as the intro in the GitHub website (README.md). This also includes other high-level topics such as the data-centric architecture.

Because the HelloWorld C core DDS and C++ HelloWorld tutorials follow the same pattern, with similar explanations (except for the code examples), I've merged them into a single tutorial, with tab groups for the C and C++ specific areas.

The code in the Core DDS (C) tutorial did not match the subscriber.c and the publisher.c code samples in the Examples > HelloWorld. Therefore, I've replaced the code with a literalinclude so that these remain in sync. For the explanatory parts of the tutorial, I've replaced the snippets with the code from subscriber.c and the publisher.c, including line numbers so that it's easier to reference them.

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Fix crash caused by security overall timeout race

This fixes a race condition in handling the "overall timeout" in the
security (handshake) state machinery: we get here

  cyclonedds/src/security/core/src/dds_security_fsm.c
  Lines 317 to 318 in 37c25f2
    struct fsm_timer_event *timer_event =
      ddsrt_fibheap_extract_min (&timer_events_fhdef, &control->timers);
    fsm_handle_timeout (control, timer_event);

so at the point of calling the handler, the "overall timeout" event is
no longer on the heap but the endtime is still < infinity, which means
the invariant that "endtime = infinity" <=> "timeout event not on heap"
doesn't hold at this point.

The handler code does update it, attempting to restore the invariant,
except it does this after allowing arbitrary state changes:

  cyclonedds/src/security/core/src/dds_security_fsm.c
  Lines 277 to 288 in 37c25f2
    case FSM_TIMEOUT_OVERALL:
      ddsrt_mutex_unlock (&control->lock);
      if (fsm->overall_timeout_action)
        fsm->overall_timeout_action (fsm, fsm->arg);
      ddsrt_mutex_lock (&control->lock);
      ...
  timer_event->endtime = DDS_NEVER;

So any code that manipulates this timeout will do the wrong thing: it
can fail to set a new timeout, or it can call ddsrt_fibheap_delete to
remove a timeout event from the heap that is no longer on it.  Both lead
to disaster, and both can happen.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Unaligned octets-to-next-header in last submessage

Octets to next header must be a multiple of 4 in all cases *except* when
it is the last submessage in the message.  That one case got overlooked
in the message validation code.  Unfortunately, it actually gets used in
practice (at least by RTI Connext Micro).

This leads to another problem: what to do if it is not a multiple of 4,
and yet the message extends beyond it?  My reading of the specification
is that it means the message is malformed.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
RTI Connext Micro, too, sends illegal ACKNACKs

... just like its big brother RTI Connext Pro and eProsima FastDDS,
where the sequence number and the bitmap length are 0.  According to
Wireshark these are pre-emptive ACKNACK messages, but they are malformed
according to DDSI 2.5, 9.4.2.6 "SequenceNumberSet":

  A valid SequenceNumberSet must satisfy the following conditions:
  - bitmapBase >= 1
  - 0 <= numBits <= 256
  - there are M=(numBits+31)/32 longs containing the pertinent bits

Cyclone already had workarounds in place for the other two, this simply
adds Connext Micro to the list.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Multiple matching networks: longest netmask wins

It turns out that configurations like:

  eth0  192.168.1.1/16
  eth1  192.168.2.1/24

occur in practice, and so the logic for determining whether an address
is "local" or not will consider an address 192.168.2.2 local for both
eth0 and eth1 (I don't see how it could do anything else, it seems to be
a legal network configuration and it certainly seems to work fine in
Linux).

This commit changes the return from the first matching one (so dependent
on the order in which the interface table was filled) to the one with
the longest netmask (assuming IP networks).  That means it will now
consistently pick eth1 in the example.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.message:
Fix CDR descr leak in type id/obj equality test

This commit replaces a call to "dds_cdrstream_desc_from_topic_desc" with
a minimal initialization of a dds_cdrstream_desc straight from the
XTypes TypeObject topic descriptor generated by IDLC, relying on a
little bit of knowledge of the type (e.g., no keys, union present) and
on a little bit of knowledge of the CDR serializer (e.g., number of
operations is not relevant for (de)serialization).

This avoids the determining the number of code words, allocating and
copying, which is rather wasteful for what really is compile-time
constant data.  The obvious alternative would have been to call
"dds_cdrstream_desc_fini".

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
IDLC option for C header guard macro name prefixes

This adds an "-f header-guard-prefix=NAME" option to the C backend for
overriding the prefix used in the generated header's multi-inclusion
guard macros.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
IDLC option for generating CDR stream descriptor

This adds a "-f cdrstream-desc" option to the C backend, which causes it
to emit a "struct dds_cdrstream_desc" in addition to the regular topic
descriptor.  There are some small differences between the two, and the
former is usually derived from the latter at run-time.

This run-time conversion involves memory allocation and determining the
number of bytes occupied by the serializer VM instructions.  Ordinarily,
it is done only when creating a topic in the API, at which point this
little bit of overhead is not an issue.

For some internal uses, in particular concerning testing type objects
for equality, this is a bit much.  Having the required representation
available as a compile-time constant is a much more attractive option.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

Currently the default participant QoS is hardcoded inside
ddsi_default_plist_participant, and not exported in the libraries
To make this follow the same pattern as the default reader/writer/etc
QoSes, the ddsi_default_qos_participant was created
As a side effect, the ddsi_default_plist_participant was no longer
necessary, as only its QoS component was used
The code was changed to use the default participant QoS in the places
where the ddsi_default_plist_participant was used previously

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Avoid referencing dds_global in dds_whc

The built-in writers of DDSI rely on the WHC implementation in DDSC,
with the WHC implementation having no dependencies on the rest of DDSC,
except for a global mutex used to construct/destruct a freelist when the
first WHC is created or the last one deleted.  This means it is
impossible to create a DDSI participant without initialising DDSC.

Changing the mutex used to one deliberately exposed by the DDSRT layer
for process-wide initialisation purposes at least solves the practical
initialisation problem.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
macOS 13 / Xcode 14 considers sprintf deprecated

... and quite rightly so.  We shouldn't be using it in general, but
rewriting mcpp to eliminate is not such a great idea either.  This
commits suppresses *all* deprecation warnings in mcpp, on the basis that
this same argument also holds for any future deprecation warnings.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Fix analyzer nullptr warn in symbol_export test

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Consistently use LIVELINESS also for participants

The liveliness QoS is only defined for endpoints, but Cyclone has
already been using it on participants to allow an application to
override the default lease duration for a participant.

The DDSI stack internally maintained a separate participant lease
duration, including in ddsi_plist_t.  This commit eliminates this
separate lease duration and consistently uses liveliness for encoding
all liveliness settings.

The price paid is a complication in (de)serialization of parameter
lists, because now a liveliness setting needs to be serialised as a
liveliness for SEDP but as a participant lease duration for SPDP, and
vice versa.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

Erik Boasson
data.message:
plist generic: use of alignof, type of enum

Some of the cases used "sizeof", some "alignof"; and some of the enum cases
used "unsigned" where others used "uint32_t". This changes them to
consistently use uint32_t.

It should make no difference in practice, but it won't do anything to
help with the -fshort-enums option of gcc ...

data.message:
Fix false-positive uninitialized typeinfo/typemap

GCC 12's analyzer gets confused in tracking the initialisation state of
typeinfo/typemap output streams in generate_type_meta_ser, apparently
caused by using the same path out of that function for success and error
cases.  Splitting the paths solves the problem.

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Rewrite IDL keylist.c to help GCC static analyzer

GCC 12's static analyzer lost track of all the dynamically allocated
arrays involved in checking key list validity.  This rewrites introduces
a simple "boxed vector" type, then reimplements the types used in terms
of this vector.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson

duplicate CU_ASSERT_FATALs.

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Fix possible null pointer dereference in ac plugin

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Suppress uninit warning in fibheap_extract_min

GCC 12's static analyzer loses track of the lazy initialization of the
array of roots in the "extract_min" operation.  Given that this function
sits in some hot loops, the obvious alternative to lazily initializing
it is not very attractive because it is sized for the worst case, which
in reality is never going to be used.

Therefore, suppressing the warning of uninitialised use appears to be
the better option.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Fix spurious format string warnings from GCC 12

If the number being formatted is near the maximum length for a 64-bit
number in decimal representation, then indeed the format string would be
too small -- but by construction the numbers are never that big.

Still, enlarging the buffer so the warning goes away is the more elegant
solution.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

from GCC 12's analyzer that turned out to be caused by the ddsrt_hh_add
taking a const argument.

data.author: Scott K Logan
data.message:
Use SHA256 digest when generating ddssec testing CA

RHEL 9 has disabled the (broken) SHA1 digest by default, resulting in 15
test failures in CycloneDDS. Switching the testing CA to use SHA256 made
all of the tests pass.

Signed-off-by: Scott K Logan <logans@cottsay.net>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Move cdrstream serializer

Moves the implementation of the CDR stream serializer out of DDSI
and makes it a separate component in Cyclone core. Both DDSC and
DDSI use this component for (de)serialization of application data
(via sertype_default in DDSC) and for (de)serialization of type
information for the XTypes type system (in DDSI via sertype_cdr).

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis@zettascale.tech>

data.author: Dennis Potman

Remove non-existing forward decl

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Move sertype default and serdata default to DDSC

This moves the default implementation for sertype and serdata (used for
application data) to the DDSC layer. Because this sertype implementation
was also used in DDSI internally for the type lookup endpoints, a new
sertype_cdr implementation is introduced. This implementation does not
support shared memory transport and supports no keys, as this is not
required for these endpoints.

With moving serdata_default, the serdatapool also moved to the DDSC layer,
from domaingv to the dds_domain object. Additionally, sertype_default in
the cdrstream interface is replaced by struct dds_cdrstream_desc (renamed
and moved ddsi_sertype_default_desc to cdrstream).

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis@zettascale.tech>

data.author: Ben Wolsieffer
data.message:
Fix assumptions that CMAKE_INSTALL_*DIR variables are relative

The CMAKE_INSTALL_*DIR variables are allowed to be absolute paths, which allows
libraries and headers to be installed into separate prefixes. This means they
cannot be naively concatenated with CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX. If an absolute path
is needed, CMAKE_INSTALL_FULL_*DIR should be used, while more complicated
handling is required to keep ${prefix} interpolation in pkg-config files in
the case where CMAKE_INSTALL_*DIR is relative.

Signed-off-by: Ben Wolsieffer <benwolsieffer@gmail.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Add "Interface" attribute to network partition

The network partitions already supported unicast addresses in the
address set, allowing one to restrict the addresses to be used for
sending data to the reader to a subset of the configured interfaces.
The problem with this model is that these unicast addresses must be
those of the host, which means the configuration necessarily becomes
machine-specific.

This commit adds an "Interface" attribute that allows one to specify a
list of interface names instead.  The addresses associated with these
interfaces are then added to the set of addresses, exactly as if adding
those addresses explicitly.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Extend is_nearby_address with SELF and UNREACHABLE

The "is_nearby_address" function returned either LOCAL (matching a local
interface) or DISTANT (anything else), but there is a real difference
between an address matching a local interface and an address belonging
to the host itself, and an even bigger difference between something
distant and an address being unreachable, e.g., because it is of wrong
locator kind.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Fix crash dropping final GAP from reorder buffer

If the following arrives from a remote writer expecting sequence number
K and with a reorder buffer limited to storing at most N sequence
numbers:

  GAP #(K+N+1) ; DATA #(K+N) .. DATA #(K+1)

then the last message (which can't be delivered yet because it was
expecting #K) will force the GAP with sequence number #(K+N+1) out.
Updating the number of discarded bytes then results in a null pointer
dereference because GAPs don't store sample info.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Free SPDP defrag/reorder in rtps_fini iso stop

The general order of initialisation/teardown is: rtps_init, rtps_start,
rtps_stop, rtps_fini.  These get allocated in rtps_init, hence it is
weird to free them in rtps_stop, and there was no reason to do it that
way.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Dennis Potman
Dennis Potman
data.message:
Fix for requesting type dependencies for incomplete type lookup response

When processing a type lookup response results in resolving a top-level
type for an endpoint, but one or more dependent types remain unresolved
(e.g. because these dependencies were not included in the type_information
for the endpoint and therefore not requested yet), the endpoint matching
is not triggered (which is reasonable, because it will fail) but there
is also no request sent for the additional types required for matching.

This commit fixes this problem by re-triggering the matching for all
endpoints that are using this type, regardless of the resolved state of
its dependencies. The matching will trigger a type lookup request in case
any dependencies need to be resolved. This fix is a temperary solution
for this problem, and will be replaced by a proper solution that
also takes find_topic calls into account (which could currently also
run into this issue).

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis@zettascale.tech>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Add validation for enum extensibility in type object

The DDS XTypes spec states that enums can be @final or @appendable
(section 7.4.1, table 12), however a comment in the IDL for the
TypeObject says that the enumerated type flag is unused. We decided
to solve this problem by ignoring the "unused" comment in the IDL and
encode the extensibility in the TypeObject. This also means that the
TypeObject validation should check for this, which is fixed in this
commit (also for aggregated types).

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis@zettascale.tech>

This fixes a bug in the type meta-data generation that prevented generating
a type object and identifier for a struct or union member of a type that is
an alias for an array of sequences of a plain type, e.g.
`typedef sequence<long> td[1];`

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis@zettascale.tech>

data.message: Add a 'presence_required' option to network interfaces to allow users to make interface presence optional.

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
macOS: if Iceoryx used, add library dir to rpath

The CMAKE_INSTALL_RPATH set in the top-level CMakeLists.txt causes the
rpath for the Iceoryx library to disappear on installation, but not
setting it means the build directories are used in the rpaths of the
installed Cyclone library, which also doesn't work.

This adds the directory where the iceoryx library is found to the rpath
used for installing.  I suspect there are better ways, but this should
be better than nothing.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Test fetching data after partial disconnect

This tests the scenario that is addressed by the preceding commit,
manipulating test flags on the writer to emulate the requisite packet
loss.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Fix stall fetching data after partial disconnect

When:

- A transient-local reader/writer pair exists with a network in between,
  and for some reason the writer's participant's lease expires at the
  reader's but not the other way around (so a "partial" or "asymmetric"
  disconnect);

- All the data published by the writer was acknowledged and no new data
  is being published;

- After rediscovery of the writer by the reader, not all historical data
  arrives on the first NACK and the heartbeat sent by writer in its
  response to the first NACK is lost; then

- The reader waits forever and retrieval of the historical data stalls.

Note that this problem exists both for application transient-local data
and for discovery data.

This commit restores Cyclone's old behaviour (pre-63b1a7179b5 or
thereabouts) of spontaneously sending NACKs at a low rate if some data
is known to be missing.

The alternative (or perhaps both should be done!) is to make the writer
start sending heartbeats when it detects a reader that suffered such an
asymmetrical disconnection.  It can detect this because it suddenly
starts receiving requests for retransmission of already acknowledged
data.

Letting the writer send heartbeats would be entirely in line with the
specification, spontaneously sending retransmit requests is not.
Nothing in the specification guarantees that the writer will send
heartbeats in this case, and so there is no interoperable solution that
adheres to the specification.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Change default AutoReschedNackDelay from 1s to 3s

This is for a rare exceptional case and so must not be default be very
aggressive.  The option didn't actually work, in the sense that no
ACKNACK message was ever generated because of it, so lengthening the
interval is not going to affect the behaviour.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Run built-in topic tests in isolation

Other code running in parallel can cause the tests to observe different
data than expected, including receiving invalid samples where none
should be.  Letting them discover other, unrelated entities would
require considerable complications in filtering out unrelated data, and
other tests actually needing such complications exist anyway.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Empty buffers on first HB is Cyclone-specific

Cyclone DDS is careful to perform a three-way handshake to have a
well-defined starting point for reliability (and hence for whether
samples can be lost despite it being reliable and the two sides being
connected all the time).

That requires dropping data until a heartbeat has been received and
starting at the highest sequence number advertised by the writer.  In
principle, this is interoperable with other implementations, but it
turns out that for the type discovery protocol (at least for OpenDDS)
this can result in dropping the first request, which (at least for
OpenDDS) stalls type discovery and prevents matching.

Hence b6dadb3439d82412b2a7492ce31017960fbb3beb changed it to accept data
from other DDS implementations before a heartbeat is received.  This
means there may be gaps in the data sequence on starting up the reliable
session if the writer is using another DDS implementation.  If this is a
problem, just use Cyclone DDS.

What did not change is that it expects to start at sequence number 1,
and it is the first heartbeat that changes that expectation.  So if,
from that other DDS implementation, the first data arrives before the
first heartbeat and it has sequence numbers > 1, it will now be buffered
and (likely) made available on receipt of the heartbeat.

The processing of the first heartbeat remained unchanged.  This means
there may be data ready for delivery where the code asserts that there
cannot be any.  The assert in itself fortunately disappears in a release
build (so there is no crash), but it does leak some memory.

With this commit the code is restructed to always use the "regular" code
path for delivery of data to avoid duplication of the delivery code.
The downside is that the (correct) assert in the case of a Cyclone
writer had to be removed.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Bump minimum CMake version to 3.16

Support for EXPORT_PROPERTIES was added in CMake 3.12, so either the
minimum version required needs to be bumped, or this feature needs to be
emulated.  Ubuntu 22.04 ships with CMake 3.16, is over two years old now
and also the minimum required for ROS 2 Foxy, so that seems like a
reasonable new minimum version.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Fix by source timestamp with more than 2 writers

Thanks to @secondage pointing out a bit of dead code (and some luck in
it ultimately getting the attention it really deserved), this commit can
now squash a bug in the "by source timestamp" destination order QoS
setting implementation.

By not setting the writer GUID associated with the latest sample pushed
into the writer, the logic checking whether the GUID of the writer or an
arriving sample with the same timestamp as the most recently insert one
can't do its job.

This adds some test cases, including one that showed the issue. They are
merely a start for writing some more tests where the effects of
various (combinations of) QoS settings get tested in an otherwise
reasonably isolated manner.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Check API behaviour when library uninitialized

Only a handful of functions actually initialize the library, all the
others rely on the handle-to-pointer conversion to protect themselves.
This adds a test that calls these functions with arguments that are not
trivially invalid, expecting error returns and no crashes.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Only inspect sertype when participant valid

The problem this addresses is very minor: anyone using
dds_create_topic_sertype ought to know better than to pass junk.  Still,
it is best not to crash when it can be trivially prevented.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Do not lookup_thread_state before pinning entity

Calling lookup_thread_state results in a crash if the library hasn't
been initialized yet, which happens as a consequence of instantiating a
domain.

All operations that need to lookup the thread state are in some way
related to an entity, and pinning an entity does check for an
uninitialized library.

This commit simply moves the handful of calls to lookup_thread_state.

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Example C program for a dynamic subscription

Waits for a publication of a given topic name to show up, then takes a
subscription to that topic and prints the samples it receives as JSON.

Caveats:

* The JSON printer makes a lot of optimistic assumptions about the
  contents and doesn't support all types.

* It is quite likely that the interpretation of the type object is
  incorrect to begin with.

Includes a publisher program that can generate a few different types.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Fix double-free in typebuilder adding struct/union

The aggregrate type gets added to the dependencies prior to calling
typebuilder_add_struct (union) and all dependencies are finalized by
ddsi_topic_descriptor_from_type, which itself is in all call paths.

Therefore the calls to the finalizer in the error handling are
incorrect.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Avoid minimal type ids in ddsi_type_get_typeinfo

The requirement on input is a complete type id that refers to a fully
resolved type, and then it constructs both the complete and the minimal
type information using that complete type.

The problem with the implementation was that the generator was
parameterized for the output kind, and called once for minimal and once
for complete type information.  Constructing the dependent type
information can require recursion, in which case it would recurse using
the just-generated minimal type ids.  Those ids need not exist yet.

This commit addresses that problem by generating both in one go, always
recursing using the complete type id.

As the number of dependent hashed type ids may be different for the
complete and the mininal type information, it now also de-dups the
dependent type ids.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Also copy serialized_size in ddsi_typeinfo_dup

Otherwise the duplicated type information for types with dependent types
is rejected as invalid when the type information retrieved from the
built-in topics is used to dynamically construct a topic for a
discovered type.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Make object to add to hash table non-const

GCC's static analyzer assumes no ownership of allocated is taken when
the object is passed to a const pointer, see for example

  https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=101713

describing the exact same case where the object is merely stored in the
hash table, and the owner of the hash table remains responsible for
freeing the memory.

Here is arguably is better to make the argument non-const anyway,
because the only way of getting the object out of the hash table
involves casting away the const.

Note that the "ehh" case is different, it copies the data.

It also turns out that changing this doesn't affect the rest of the code
base other than some wrapper functions in test code.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Mark intentional odd memset in test (CID 355065)

Coverity rightly warns about memsetting 8 bytes in a larger struct that
looks like an incorrect initialisation, but that is done intentionally
here to construct an invalid type id.

Annotate the memset to silence Coverity and add a static assertion that
the struct indeed is large enough.

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Drop MinGW build from CI

Something changed somewhere in the MinGW setup on Azure because it
started failing with the following error (with some editing to reduce
line length):

    -- Check for working C compiler: C:/msys64/mingw64/bin/gcc.exe
    -- Check for working C compiler: C:/msys64/mingw64/bin/gcc.exe - broken
    CMake Error at C:/Program Files/CMake/share/cmake-3.23/Modules/CMakeTestCCompiler.cmake:69 (message):
      The C compiler

        "C:/msys64/mingw64/bin/gcc.exe"

      is not able to compile a simple test program.

      It fails with the following output:

        Change Dir: D:/a/1/s/build/CMakeFiles/CMakeTmp

        Run Build
        Command(s):C:/ProgramData/chocolatey/bin/mingw32-make.exe \
            -f Makefile cmTC_7f05c/fast && \
            C:/ProgramData/chocolatey/lib/mingw/tools/install/mingw64/bin/mingw32-make \
            -f CMakeFiles\cmTC_7f05c.dir\build.make CMakeFiles/cmTC_7f05c.dir/build
        mingw32-make[1]: Entering directory 'D:/a/1/s/build/CMakeFiles/CMakeTmp'
        Building C object CMakeFiles/cmTC_7f05c.dir/testCCompiler.c.obj
        C:\msys64\mingw64\bin\gcc.exe \
            -o CMakeFiles\cmTC_7f05c.dir\testCCompiler.c.obj \
            -c D:\a\1\s\build\CMakeFiles\CMakeTmp\testCCompiler.c
        mingw32-make[1]: *** [CMakeFiles\cmTC_7f05c.dir\build.make:77: \
            CMakeFiles/cmTC_7f05c.dir/testCCompiler.c.obj] Error 1
        mingw32-make[1]: Leaving directory 'D:/a/1/s/build/CMakeFiles/CMakeTmp'
        mingw32-make: *** [Makefile:126: cmTC_7f05c/fast] Error 2

At this point, `gcc` has already been used successfully for building
CUnit and OpenSSL, therefore it must have something to do with how CMake
invokes it.  Unfortunately, the error message tells us little, locally
it doesn't reproduce and a days' worth of trying to fix this using
either the windows-2019 or the windows-2022 image (that by the way fail
in totally different ways) has yielded exactly nothing.

To have a perennially broken CI build is not acceptable and the
investment for fixing it seems to be higher than reasonable for such a
niche platform.  This commit drops it from the CI matrix.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Refactoring and bugfixes for find_topic

This fixes a number of bugs in the find topic implementation, and
also include some minor refactoring.
- Type information to compare with the type info search parameter should
  not be retrieved from the qos of the ktopic (which cannot have it
  because a ktopic has a 1..n relation with topics, which can have
  different types). Instead, the sertype of the topic itself is used
  in pin_if_matching_topic (via find_local_topic_pp)
- Type information is made an optional parameter for dds_find_topic,
  and if provided, the type information is validated
- lookup_topic_definition is changed so that in case no type information
  (complete type id from the type information), there will be no check
  if multiple topics with the provided name exist. It will just return
  an arbitrary topic definition with that name (reading DCPSTopic would
  be a better alternative in that case).
- Improve documentation of public API for dds_find_topic (and _scoped)
- Fix the find_topic_local and find_topic_global tests: pass the type
  information parameter to find_topic.
- Allow the create_topic tests to create a topic with the same name
  but different type.

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis@zettascale.tech>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Fix issue in IDLC related to nested include files (#1324)

* Fix issue in IDLC related to nested include files

This fixes the issue in IDLC that when using input files that have nested
include files, the conversion of the relative to absolute path in IDLC is
incorrect when popping sources files from the stack in the push_line
function. This issue resulted in no output from IDLC, but it also didn't
report an error.

This commit changes the way files are popped from the stack based on
the processor filemakers: it assumes that for every START_OF_FILE there
is a corresponding RETURN_TO_FILE to return to the parent file, and
therefore there is no need to convert the relative path to an absolute
path when processing a RETURN_TO_FILE marker.

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis@zettascale.tech>

* Fix code comment indentation

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis@zettascale.tech>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Remove sertype ref from ddsi_type and proxy_endpoint_common

In the former cyclone specific implementation of type discovery,
a sertype was created at the moment a remote type was resolved. To
keep the refcount for this sertype > 0, the proxy endpoints that
were using it had a reference to this sertype. With the implementation
of the XTypes based type discovery, the type meta-data (type ids
and objects) are stored in the type library, and no sertype is
created upon receiving complete type meta-data. This commit
removes the reference to a sertype from proxy_endpoint_common.

In addition, the sertype ref is also removed from ddsi_type, which
was there to get a type information object for a type when sending
an SEDP message. We can now use the type meta-data stored in the type
library to generate the type information object used in SEDP.

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis@zettascale.tech>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Public API changes for find_topic

Update the public API for finding a topic or resolving a topic
descriptor:
- Refactor the existing dds_find_topic function (that has been
deprecated for some time) so that it can be used for find a topic
by its name and type information (from discovery data). This
replaces dds_find_topic_scoped, which is deprecated now.
- Replace dds_resolve_type by dds_create_topic_descriptor, which
allows to get a topic descriptor by a type_info object, optionally
waiting for the type to become available.
- dds_builtintopic_get_endpoint_typeid is changed so that it returns
the type_information and not only a single type identifier.

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis@zettascale.tech>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Type object to topic descriptor transformation

This adds the implementation for generating Cyclone topic descriptors
from XTypes type meta-data. Using type identifiers that are included in
endpoint and topic discovery data (in the form of a type information
object), the type meta-data, which is a set of type objects for the type
identifiers and its dependencies, can be retrieved using the type
lookup service.

The function ddsi_topic_descriptor_from_type that is added in this
commit, implements the transformation from a ddsi_type (that wraps
a XTypes type) to a dds_topic_descriptor_t, that includes the type
meta data required by the cdrstream serializer to read and write
serialized data for this type.

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis@zettascale.tech>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Update "perftest" script configuration settings

This script was overlooked when updating the configuration settings on
two points:

* Moving the default lease duration to the Discovery section
* Improving the way socket buffer sizes get specified

The old settings are still handled, but it shouldn't trigger any
deprecation warnings.  The new way of specifying socket receive buffer
sizes also distinguishes between what to ask for and what the require.
This should prevent an error on many Linux systems in the default
configuration.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.message:
Fix TOCTOU on /proc/self/cmdline (CID 352837)

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Use C11 _Alignof function for alignment

All supported compilers have support for the C11 _Alignof keyword,
so we can rely on this for the alignment used in the topic descriptor.
This replaces the custom implementation of alignment calculation
in idlc, that in certain cases reported the wrong alignment when
using external or optional members.

This also replaces the alignof macro that was defined and used in
whc and plist code with the dds_alignof macro added in ddsrt.

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis@zettascale.tech>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Only add DDS_OP_FLAG_MU for explicit key members

The must-understand flag should only be set in the serializer instructions
for key members that are explicitly marked as key in the IDL, not for
implicit keys (through their parent member's key attribute), because these
members shouldn't be considers must-understand when used as a non-key
member.

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Naming consistency in thread state

Cleans up some of the weird and inconsistent naming that (if I recall
correctly) has its roots in an ancient bit of refactoring:

* thread_state1 => thread_state
* ts1 => thrst
* ts (where it stands for thread state) => thrst

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Remove thread count limit

This removes the fixed (if somewhat configurable) limit on the number of
threads that has been plaguing people for quite some time (especially
those who tried to use the multi-threaded executor of ROS 2 on machines
with high core counts).

It does this by replacing the array with threads states with a list of
arrays, pushing a new block to the front of the list whenever no slot is
available at the time a new thread is created/discovered.

The (optional) thread liveliness monitoring adjusts itself whenever it
discovers the list has grown, for the rest, it merely changes a few
loops.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Drew Hoener
data.message:
(idlc) Add options for output directory and path reconstruction / prefix (#1263)

* Add options for output directory and path reconstruction (#1220)

Added -o command line option to specify an output directory which may or may not exist.
Added -b command line option to specify a base path for a directory structure.
When using -b, any directories from <base_dir> to <file> will be reconstructed in the output directory. If no output directory is specified, this will result in files being compiled in-place.
Necessary directories will be constructed automatically to hold the output files

Signed-off-by: Andrew Hoener <ahoener@boston-engineering.com>

* Extracted path generation to its own functions.
Added unit tests

Signed-off-by: Andrew Hoener <ahoener@boston-engineering.com>

* Updated Generate.cmake to use the new output_dir by default.
Added BASE_DIR option to specify the base dir for the program

Signed-off-by: Andrew Hoener <ahoener@boston-engineering.com>

Fix wrong unlock in participant sec attributes

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Set CMake CMP0075 policy to NEW

CMP0075 concerns a change in behaviour in the combination of
check_include_files and CMAKE_REQUIRED_LIBRARIES. This combination
occurs on Windows, and in this case both the old and the new behaviour
are acceptable.

We support CMake versions older than the one where the policy was
introduced, so select the new behaviour only if the policy actually
exists.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Increase timeout in test "sync_reader_writer"

Timing out after 1s would seem to be reasonable, but in reality seems to
result in CI flakiness for some tests (e.g., CUnit_ddsc_xtypes_basic at
the time of this comment).  A hypothesis is that some of the tests that
happen to run in parallel cause so much load and network traffic that
there is the occasional bit of packet loss, and if that affects
discovery packets, it could plausibly make it take longer than 1s.

Given that some of the tests running in parallel are ones that
intentionally generate massive amounts of discovery traffic for topics
and types, I think this hypothesis is plausible.

Increasing the timeout by quite a bit if "expect_sync" is set (which it
is here) should not introduce any new problems as a timeout here results
in immediate test failure.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Use liveliness QoS for participant lease duration

The DDSI spec defines a "participant lease duration" at the protocol
level without defining a mechanism for configuring it.  Traditionally
Cyclone DDS made it possible to configure it via the LeaseDuration
setting, this commit adds the possibility for an application to
manipulate it via the participant QoS.

Given that the spec says the liveliness QoS is applicable only to the
topic, reader and writer, and that the "participant lease duration"
exactly matches what one expects from an "automatic" liveliness kind, it
seems perfectly reasonable to configure this via the liveliness QoS on
the participant.  This liveliness setting is then also propagated into
the built-in topics.

This does result in a change in behaviour for those applications that
create a single QoS object containing a liveliness setting that they
then use for creating the participant and a reader/writer.  Without
these changes, the participant would ignore it, now it will use the
value (or reject it, if it is not "automatic").

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson

which includes this

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Do not force XCDR1 default for DATA_REPRESENTATION

Simply merging in the default reader/writer QoS causes it to pick up the
hard-coded XCDR1 that is specified for the discovery protocol.  This
then means that "ensure_valid_data_representation" can only accept or
reject the setting, instead of being able to pick a sensible default
based on the type definition.  The end result is that an application
would be forced to explicitly select XCDR2 for topics that require it.
That's not good.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson

Fix compiler warnings in test case
