data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Data representation qos refactoring

Some refactoring of the implementation of the data representation
qos: in discovery data, consider an empty list of values as not present,
so that the default (single value XCDR1) will be merged in the qos, and
the qos matching code can safely assume that the data representation qos
is always present and has at least 1 value.

Also add a check in deser_data_representation to ensure that the buffer
has sufficient bytes remaining to the provided data representation
value count, to avoid allocating a large amount of memory (e.g. in case
of a malicious node that send a large count).

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis.potman@adlinktech.com>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Fix data representation in RTPS encapsulation identifier

The RTPS encapsulation identifier should correspond to the encoding
version and data representation of the outermost object of the type
used for a topic. This commit fixes the issue that Cyclone was using
an incorrect value for this identifier when writing data for a topic
with an appendable or mutable top-level type.

The Cyclone deserializer uses the data representation as provided
in the serializer instructions for that type, but did not check that
the encapsulation identifier in the RTPS submessage indicates the
same data representation. This commit also introduces that check.

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis.potman@adlinktech.com>

In most tests the extensibility of the types used is not relevant.
Therefore, the IDL files do not explicitly set the extensibility and
use the default. IDLC warns about implicit extensibility because the
default (currently final) may change to appendable (in the spec).
For all cases where this warning is not relevant (because a specific
extensibility is not needed), this commit disables the warning.

data.message:
Add default_extensibility option to idlc

Add a command line option to IDLC to set the default extensibility
for aggregated (and also for enumerated types when extensibility for these
types is added). Types that do not have their extensibility explicitly set,
get the provided default extensibility. In case no default is provided,
'final' is used. Because this is different than the default in the XTypes
spec (which is 'appendable'), a warning is shown in case there are aggregated
types in the IDL that do not have an explicit extensibility set and no
default is provided by the command line option.

Some refactoring of the IDL compiler config for parser and generators.
The parser config is moved to a struct 'config' in pstate, to separate
config from state for the parser (more settings will be added e.g. by
the default-extensibility option).

For generators, config is moved from pstate to a separate parameter of the
generate function, so that pstate includes only config for IDL parsing and
does not include generator specific config.

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Bounded sequences

Adds the implementation of bounded sequences in IDLC and the
cdrstream serializer. A new serializer instruction BSQ is
introduced, that has a bound parameter and is handled similar
to the existing SEQ instruction.

Serialization of a sample that has a sequence-type member containing
more elements than the specified bound will fail. For incoming
data, deserialization (normalize) also fails in case a sequence
has an elements count that is larger than its bound (the sample
will be dropped in that case).

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis.potman@adlinktech.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Unsigned sequence numbers 2: struct{uint64}->uint64

For the most part, a mechanical transformation:

* "v" -> a new unique identifier X using refactoring tools
* a manual cleanup for the (*V).X cases
* a bit of regex-editing to remove ".X"
* a bit of regex-editing to remote the (seqno_t){ V } compound literals
* a manual fixup of now superfluous braces around scalars in a handful
  of initializers

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Unsigned sequence numbers 1: int64->struct{uint64}

Sequence numbers are spec'd as signed and were, sadly, implemented as
int64_t in the code base. There are various places in the code
where (sequence number + 1) is used, for example in the buffering
incoming messages while restoring order, and that means some important
invariants turn out to be non-invariants and undefined behaviour is
triggered. I don't know which of the two is worse.

With valid sequence numbers in [1,2**63-1], the options are:

* Full rewrite of a lot of logic, to never add 1 to a sequence number.
  Not nice.

* Changing the message validation code to discard and/or rewrite
  messages so that the remainder of the code never observes
  2**63-1. Effective and simple, but forgivable only in dire
  circumstances.

* Changing the internal representation to uint64_t, with careful manual
  verification that it never accidentally underflows.  This is in my
  view the best option.

Fortunately, there are very few places where a sequence number is the
left operand of a subtraction, and only a few odd places where -1 is
used.

This reworks everything by changing it not merely from an int64_t to an
uint64_t, but also wrapping the uint64_t inside a struct to guarantee
that all relational and arithmetical operations become compile-time
errors.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Replace int64_t by seqno_t in security messages

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Use gapstart=0 rather than -1 for initial gap_info

A magic value of -1 is problematic when changing the representation of
sequence numbers to uint64_t, necessitating going over the code to
update all (fortunately, few) places where it is used.  The fields were
always both -1 or both > 0. So replacing the somewhat odd magic value of
-1 with the more customary 0 makes the most sense.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Use min=max=0 rather than -1 to indicate empty WHC

A magic value of -1 is problematic when changing the representation of
sequence numbers to uint64_t, necessitating going over the code to
update all (fortunately, few) places where it is used.  The fields were
always both -1 or both > 0. So replacing the somewhat odd magic value of
-1 with the more customary 0 makes the most sense.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Refactor sequence number validation

* Factor out the validation of a sequence number into a separate
  function.

* Consider a sequence number or fragment number set where the final
  number is beyond the allowed range (i.e., ACKNACK with bitmap_base =
  2**63-1, numbits = 256) as malformed.

* Same for fragment numbers.

Arguably, a sequence number set with base = 2**63-1 and size 1 ought to
be allowed (and analogous for fragment numbers) but it adds significant
complexity without much benefit (although it would be different when the
sequence number representation changes to uint64_t).

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Fix get_typelookup_writer racing new_participant

A new (local) participant is made visible in the entity index before
creating the built-in writers, to avoid complications in the matching.
This is generally fine, they don't get used until later on anyway,
except in those cases where one tries to use a built-in writer by simply
scanning all the participants.  And this is what the
get_typelookup_writer does.

The result is that calling get_builtin_writer may find that the
requested writer doesn't exist (yet, in this case), causing it to fall
back to the "privileged participant" without that "privileged
participant" being set for the participant.  This causes an assertion
failure.

This commit replaces a boolean value tracking the progress of deleting
the participant to a enum that allows one to mark also check progress in
initialization.  Any participant not yet ready is then simply skipped,
avoiding the race.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Fix rare crash on queueing messages for retransmit

The retransmit queue tracks messages by writer GUID, sequence number and
fragment number. If a duplicate is presented for insertion in the queue,
it first tries to merge it, enqueueing it only if that fails.  The cases
where it fails are exceedingly rare, but if it does, it would end up
trying to insert a second entry with the same key in an AVL tree that
doesn't allow duplicates, leading to a crash (an assertion in a debug
build, a null pointer dereference in a release one).

This commit marks a duplicate message such that it is not entered in the
table at all.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Initialize instance id generator from /dev/urandom

... or equivalent on other platforms.

The reason is forking: ddsrt gets initialized once and therefore the
child process gets the same random generator state as the parent. That
means a process doing

  main () {
    if (fork () == 0)
      create_participant
    else
      create_participant
  }

ends up with the same IIDs and (worse) the same GUIDs.  And that is not
supposed to ever happen.

Note that we can't do pthread_atfork for the global random generator
(no matter how good well it would work for the forking itself) because
there is no way to *remove* the at-fork handler.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

removed (f6de22e59905c7ecb6076c3039305fc5d2d2a826) but the corresponding
entry for forwarding from deprecated configurations from before the
multi-domain support still existed.

The consequence of that doubly-deprecated entry is that specifying

configuration processing.

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Add "none" transport option for fuzzing

This builds on the pre-existing "vnet" transport by fleshing out a few
missing parts and making it selectable in the configuration.  When
selected all normal initialization happens, including looking for a
network interface, the only significant difference is that the network
receive threads are not started.

Participant discovery messages are disabled via pre-existing tricks, and
with the absence of incoming traffic, no discovery will take place.
That guarantees no packets will ever need to be sent and the absence of
recv/send functions in the transport is not an issue.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Implementation of the XTypes type system in DDSI

This commit contains the implementation of the XTypes type system in DDSI. This replaces
the current implementation that is using proprietary type identifiers (a hash of a serialized
sertype) and sends serialized sertypes in discovery data. The new implementation uses the
Type Identifier and Type Objects as defined in the DDS XTypes specification.

- The type meta-data library is restructured and partly re-implemented, so that it can
  handle minimal and complete type identifiers and their corresponding type objects.
- The type lookup service endpoints are now using request and response types that
  comply with the XTypes specification.
- The implementation of the assignability check is based on the rules as defined in the XTypes
  specification and uses the (discovered) type identifier and (minimal or complete) type
  object to check the assignability of types used by the endpoints.
- The IDL compiler C backend is extended with a module that outputs type meta-data as part
  of the generated topic descriptor. Including the type meta-data can be disabled using the
  '-t' command line option. The descriptors gets two XCDR2 blobs:
    - serialized TypeInformation, which contains the type identifier (minimal and complete)
      of the top-level type and its dependent type identifiers.
    - serialized TypeMap, which maps the type identifiers used in the TypeInformation to
      the TypeObjects.
- Discovery data now contains the type information parameter (id 0x0075), which replaces
  the proprietary parameter that was used in the old implementation.

Open issues and unsupported features:
- The conversion from a (complete) type object to a sertype is not implemented
  yet. As a result, it is not possible to create a topic based on a discovered
  type and topic discovery for remote topics (find_topic functions) is not working.
- Strongly connected components are not supported, and therefore recursive types
  cannot be used with type-id/object generation enabled in the IDL compiler.
- Missing support for specific xtypes features:
  - explicit defaults (@default annotation) for members of aggregated types
  - try-construct annotation
  - extensibility 'mutable' for union and bitmask types
  - map and bitset data-types
  - inheritance for unions and bitset types
  - must-understand annotation
  - @external annotation on collection element type
  - using struct, union, array (with non-primitive element type), sequence type
    members as (part of the) key
  - built-in annotations min, max, unit
  - verbatim annotations

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis.potman@adlinktech.com>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Fix idl_strip for typedefs to array

Changes the idl_strip function so that it only resolves forward
declarations and alias types, and not arrays. By using the specific
flags for typedefs to array and non-array types, it can be used as
replacement for the idl_unalias function.

This also changes the idl_is_alias function back the behavior before
PR #1068, which allowed array to be an alias. This, in combination
with different flags passed in calls to idl_strip from emit_array,
fixes issue #1079.

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis.potman@adlinktech.com>

data.message:
Ignore submessages with vendor-specific entity ids

Entity ids in submessage headers (readerId & writerId) should be of the
correct entity kind and it is sensible to treat the message as malformed
if they aren't.  Vendor-specific entity ids need not follow the pattern,
and so these need to be ignored.

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Check reader/writer entity id kind in submessage

For all submessages containing a writerId in the header, that id must
have a kind "writer". There are no submessages for which the "unknown
id" for the writer makes sense. Similarly, the readerId fields must be
of the "reader" kind, or, for all cases other than AKNACK and NACKFRAG,
the "unknown id".

The GUID lookup functions do check that whatever is found is actually of
the correct type, but they are not supposed to be used for input
validation and assert that the GUID passed in is of the correct
kind. Passing garbage into a release build is therefore harmless, but in
debug build can cause assertion failures.

If another vendor uses different entity kinds in these locations, those
will now lead to warnings about malformed messages.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Accept only GUIDs of the correct kind in discovery

A DCPSPublication message ought to contain an endpoint GUID with an
entity kind "writer".  Furthermore, while a participant GUID in such a
message is neither required nor used by Cyclone, if it is present, it
ought to be for the same participant.

DCPSSubscription and DCPSTopic are analogous.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

  src/ddsrt/src/avl.c:419:5: error: use of NULL ‘vnode’ where non-null
    expected [CWE-690] [-Werror=analyzer-null-argument]

this is nonsense, possibly caused by a null pointer check in
cnode_from_onode().

This commit adds a few conversion functions that omit the null pointer
check and are annotated as requiring a non-null pointer and uses them
where applicable.  Various non-null annotations got added as well.

data.message:
Check all buffer bounds in cdrstream normalization

This adds input buffer bounds checking for:

* declared header size in delimited formats with respect to input
* content of delimited format with respect to declared size
* PL member headers with respect to declared PL encoding block
* PL members with respect to the declared member size

overflows ...).

It also adds error propagation in normalizing keys and parameter list
members.

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Fix domain tag leak if present in >1 config frags

The code for overwriting a configuration element set by an earlier
configuration fragment frees the old value only if the multiplicity is
1, on the grounds that in other cases they would be combined one way or
another.

This commit fixes the multiplicity for three cases where it was set to 0
incorrectly:

* Domain/Tag, where it caused a memory leak
* Domain/Discovery/EnableTopicDiscoveryEndpoints, a boolean and
  therefore harmless

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
ddsperf: fix deadlock in monitoring discovery

Calling create_reader from within a subscription_matched listener can
cause a deadlock by a thread biting its own tail. This is an accepted
consequence of the synchronous listeners, but it is a nasty pitfall that
gets everyone eventually ...

Deadlock signature:

  log_stacktrace_sigh + 30
  _sigtramp + 29
  libsystem_blocks.dylib + 1808
  ddsrt_cond_wait + 9
  dds_reader_status_cb + 75
  connect_writer_with_reader_wrapper + 801
  generic_do_match + 1104
  new_writer_guid + 751
  new_writer + 266
  dds_create_writer + 766
  participant_data_listener + 1520
  endpoint_matched_listener + 45
  dds_reader_status_cb + 1524
  connect_writer_with_reader_wrapper + 1066
  generic_do_match + 1104
  new_reader_guid + 3017
  new_reader + 270
  dds_create_reader_int + 944
  main + 3797
  start + 1

It would probably be best to implement asynchronous listener invocations
and make the current synchronous listeners opt-in for those cases where
the timing guarantees of the synchronous ones matter.  For now, however,
solve the problem internally in ddsperf by enqueuing the synchronous
events for eventual processing.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Fix concurrent hopscotch test GC emulation

Instead of implementing a "proper" GC that frees the memory shortly
after it becomes safe to do so, the concurrent hopscotch test defers the
freeing until the very of the test. It did this by overwriting the first
few bytes of the block with a singly linked list, even though the data
may still be used afterward.

The first few bytes of the block are the size of the bucket array, and
overwriting with some pointer means a concurrent lookup can end up
calculating a bucket index that is way outside the array, leading to a
segmentation fault.

This is the suspected cause of the observed occasional failure of this
test in the CI.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Refactoring and bugfixes in @optional implementation

Minor refactoring and fixes for some issues in the implementation
of the optional annotation:
- fix memory leak when re-using a buffer for reading multiple
  samples with optional fields: a free_sample is called for the
  optional member when a buffer is allocated and the field is
  not present in the next sample
- add a test-case for re-using a sample buffer with optional
  members that are randomly set/not-set
- move the check for optional-field-present in cdr to a function
- in IDLC, don't set the FLAG_EXT for string types, as these are
  mapped to a pointer type and don't need the de-reference
- for optional members, also set FLAG_EXT because optional members
  are mapped to a pointer type
- replace `read_and_normalize_uint8` with `read_and_normalize_bool`

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis.potman@adlinktech.com>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
xcdr version check for optional members

This commit updates the check for required xcdr version in the
cdrstream serializer. The function `dds_stream_has_dynamic_type`
is replaced by `dds_stream_minimum_xcdr_version` and now also
takes usage of `@optional` into account (which is not supported
for xcdr1 in this serializer). A test is added to check the
correct xcdr version for specific types.

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
@optional support in idlc and cdrstream serializer

This commits adds support for the @optional annotation in idl. This
annotation can be used on struct members. An optional member is
generated as a pointer type in the idlc output, similar to external
members. In plain and delimited CDR the field is preceded by a bool
that indicates if the field is present (in pl-cdr the field is
omitted if not present).

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis.potman@adlinktech.com>

data.author: Chris Lalancette
data.message:
Fix warning when building CycloneDDS with gcc 11.

gcc 11 warns that there is a conversion from 'long int'
to 'uint32_t' when assigning the value of PTHREAD_STACK_MIN
to tattr.stackSize.  It's pedantically correct; tattr.stackSize
is a uint32_t, and PTHREAD_STACK_MIN is either an integer (if
it is hard-coded), or the result of calling sysconf(), which
always returns a long.  In either case it is a signed value,
so we should explicitly cast it to uint32_t here.  This quiets
the warning.

Signed-off-by: Chris Lalancette <clalancette@openrobotics.org>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Remove BSP instruction for cdrstream serializer

The BSP instruction was added to represent a bounded string
type as a pointer, in addition to the BST instruction that is a
bounded string represented as a char array. With the introduction
of the @external annotation, it is possible to mark a bounded string
as external data (i.e. a pointer), so there is no need for having
a separate BSP instruction.

Because the BSP instruction was not yet used by idlc, it can be
removed without any backward compatiblity issues. The instruction
type code (0x0b) is reserved for future use, to avoid changing
the type code for other instructions.

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis.potman@adlinktech.com>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Modify type generation for array of bounded strings

In the idlc C generator, the type for a member that is an array of
bounded strings should be: char member[array-len][str-sz]
This commit fixes the generator so that the dimensions of the
array and string are in the correct order.

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis.potman@adlinktech.com>

data.message:
Fix for using uninitialized bool in topickind_qos_match_p_lock

When matching endpoints, in the case the topic name or type
name does not match and the remote endpoint does not include a
type identifier, the bool variables that indicate if a type
lookup request should be done are used uninitialized in
topickind_qos_match_p_lock. This resulted in requesting type
details for an empty type id.

This commit fixes the issue by initializing these boolean values
to false in qos_match_mask_p before other checks are done.

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Fix new_proxy_topic race on topic definition refc

new_proxy_topic got a pointer to a topic definition by calling
"lookup" (not the "_locked" version), which could result in allocating a
new topic definition and adding it to the topic_defs hash table while
initializing its refcount to 0.  The refcount would then later on be
incremented (and outside the correct lock).

If a local topic with an identical definition were to be created and
deleted in between creating the topic definition with refcount 0 in
new_proxy_topic and the increment of the refcount, that local topic
would reuse the definition.  Deleting the local topic would cause the
refcount to drop to 0, and so the definition would be removed it from
the hash table and freed.

The result is a dangling pointer in the proxy topic.

This requires both a local and a proxy topic with the same definition,
because the local ones do the refcounting and hash table operations
atomically, and all discovery work is strictly serialized in the
dq.builtins thread.  So either by itself will not cause any trouble.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
waitset_torture: no check handle table gets freed

Windows x64 Release builds started failing this check, and the proximate
cause is that the thread cleanup routines are not called for all
threads, leaving the slots for two of the worker threads occupied while
shutting down Cyclone and so also leaving the handle table in place.
This then results in a BAD_PARAMETER error instead of a
PRECONDITION_NOT_MET one.

I have no clue why those cleanup routines do not get called.  But it is
not this test that should be sensitive to this difference.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Avoid duplicate dheader in CDR for appendable structs with base type

This commit fixes the issue that an extra DHEADER is included in the
CDR when serializing an appendable struct that inherits from a base
type. The base type's members should be serialized as if these were
part of the derived type. The DDS_OP_FLAG_BASE is used to indicate
that an EXT field (the 'parent' field that refers to the base type)
is a special case, and the serializer handles this by skipping the
DLC instruction of the base type. This results in the base type
being serialized as if it is final, without the DHEADER.

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis.potman@adlinktech.com>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Fix serialization for mutable struct inheritance

For mutable structs, the serializer should not include a 'parent'
PL member in the CDR. This commit fixes this issue by adding a flag
DDS_OP_FLAG_BASE to the PLM instruction to instruct the serializer
to include the PL member list from a base type in the type that
is being processed. For final and appendable struct, the implementation
remains unchanged and is using the 'parent' member in the serializer
to include the base type members.

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis.potman@adlinktech.com>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Struct inheritance in idlc

This adds support for struct inheritance to the C generator of the IDL
compiler (inheritance for union types is not yet supported). As described
in section 7.5.1.4.1.3 of the XTypes spec, in the generated types the
inheritance is "as if an instance of the base type were the first
member of the subtype with the name 'parent'". As a result, in the
generated opcodes for the serializer the base type is also included
as if it is a member of the base type.

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis.potman@adlinktech.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Stricter test for use of Iceoryx

When data should have been handed off for delivery via Iceoryx but is
not, the native short-circuiting for local readers is not suppressed and
local readers still get the data. The "iceoryx" tests did not account
for this possibility.

This commit temporarily "adjusts" the set of matched local readers to
prevent this path from working. This way, if the data is never handed
off to Iceoryx when it should have been, the local readers do not get
any data and an error is signalled.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Provide more control over socket buffer sizes

It used to only be possible to specify a minimum buffer size, with an
inability to get that minimum size a hard error. In particular, it was
impossible to configure the size to request if one was willing to accept
anything, so trying to get 4MB while accepting whatever is given was not
a possibility.

This commit moves the MinimumSocket{Send,Receive}BufferSize elements to
the "min" attribute of Socket{Send,Receive}BufferSize and adds a "max"
attribute. The behaviour is described by this table:

  if (min, max)=   and   initbuf=   then  request=  and  result=
     (def, def)          < defmin         defmin         whatever it is
     (def, N)            anything         N              whatever it is
     (M,   def)          < M              M              error if < M
     (M,   N<M)          < M              M              error if < M
     (M,  N>=M)          anything         N              error if < M
  where defmin = 1MB for receive buffer, 64kB for send buffer
        "def" stands for the "default" value of in "min" or "max"

The default settings match the original behaviour: default/default for
the receive buffer size and 64kB/default. But it is now also possible to
specify min=default and max=4MB to request a 4MB buffer but continue
with whatever is the result after the setsockopt call.

Note that some operating systems will set the buffer size to the maximum
allowed if a larger buffer size is requested while some others return an
error and leave it unchanged (macOS is one of those). This error is
ignored as long as the resulting buffer size is larger than the minimum.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
More stack frames in "other" thread backtrace test

The test wants to see at least 3 stack frames (an arbitrary number; and
only if there are any at all) but the a thread doing nothing but waiting
on a condition variable need not have that many and it doesn't even
guarantee that it is blocking on a condition variable at the time it
tries to get a stack trace.  At least on Windows this has given rise to
some test flakiness.

This changes the "other" test case in two ways:

* It forces two additional stack frames onto the stack by walking
  a (single-node, hard-coded) AVL tree.  The AVL tree walker is
  implemented in the core library, so there's no way this call can be
  inlined.

* It only tries to get a stack trace once it has been established that
  this callback function has indeed been called.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Fixed-key flags in topic descriptor for XCDR1 and XCDR2

This commit fixes a bug in the calculation of the key size
in the idl descriptor generator. This size is used to set
the fixed_key flags in the topic descriptor.

In addition to fixing the existing flag, there is also an
additional flag DDS_TOPIC_FIXED_KEY_XCDR2 introduced that
indicates if the XCDR2 serialized key is static (in other
words: guaranteed to fit in 16 bytes). The existing flag
DDS_TOPIC_FIXED_KEY indicates the same for XCDR1 encoded
keys. A test is added that checks the flags and the
calculated key-size.

The implementation of get_keyhash in serdata_default is
also changed, to take the different key-size for XCDR1 and
XCDR2 into account.

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis.potman@adlinktech.com>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Bugfix for enum and bitmask union members

This fixes a bug in the emit_case function for union members
for members with bitmask and enum type-spec. Bitmask members
were incorrectly handled as IN_UNION, but should be INLINE
because the OP_TYPE_nBY is used.
Enum members should be handled as IN_UNION, but were INLINE
and failed because of an incorrect assert.

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis.potman@adlinktech.com>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Add 1BY alignment for union types

When stashing an opcode for a union type in idlc, set the alignment
to 1BY. This ensures that the alignment is set for a type that only
contains members with union type-spec, and not any other members
(which can theoretically occur when using recursive union types).

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis.potman@adlinktech.com>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Fix prefixing forward declared structs and unions

In the types generated by the IDL compiler, prefixing a struct
or union type with 'struct' is only required in case it refers
to a forward declared type. But in a direct recursive types, the
actual type and not the forward is used as type_spec for the
member. So this commit changes the check whether to add the
'struct' prefix to also include any struct or union type_spec.

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis.potman@adlinktech.com>

Because the idl compiler in Cyclone does not include OpenSplice XML type
descriptors (like the old java based compiler did), the cdrtest that
checks interoperability between Cyclone and OpenSplice needs to be updated.

This commit adds a cmake module for finding an OpenSplice installation (e.g.
a source build of the community edition). The idl compiler from this OpenSplice
installation is used to compile the idl generated by the perl script in this
test. The output is transformed and included in the test program, so that an

Key order in extract_key_from_data

Some refactoring of the cdrstream serializer, to use correct key
field order (by the field's member id) in extract_key_from_data.
The key descriptor is extended with an index value per key field,
which indicates the index of that key field in the CDR. This allows
to efficiently extract the key from the CDR of a sample and get
a serialized key in the correct order.

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Key order for keylist notation

This changes the key order when using keylist notation for keys in idl.
With these changes in place, there is no difference in key field order
between the @key annotation and pragma keylist notation for keys. In both
cases, the fields used in the key for a type are sorted by there member
id (which is scoped to the containing type).

A test is included that tests several variants for both @key and keylist.

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
Data-representation in endpoint and topic QoS

This firstly introduces a derived sertype for readers and writers,
that uses the data representation as specified in the QoS.

Secondly, this changes ensure the correct data-representation (XCDR version)
is stored in the endpoint and topic qos. Invalid combinations of
extensibility of the (nested) types used in a topic and the data-representation
set via the qos will result in a bad_parameter error when creating a topic,
reader or writer.

If no data-representation is set in the QoS, a sensible value will be chosen
by Cyclone. This commit includes some tests for use of the data representation
QoS.

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis.potman@adlinktech.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Verify an MD5 collision only affects DDSI keyhash

The DDSI protocol defines a "keyhash" that is the computed from the
big-endian CDR of the key with any padding cleared
as follows:

* if the maximum length of that blob given the key types is at most 16
  bytes and the DDS Security settings allow a plain-text keyhash, the
  keyhash is that CDR padded out to 16 bytes with zeros;

* in all other cases, it is the MD5 of the CDR blob.

That means any (*) pair of instances where the MD5 hash of the keys
happens to be the same get the same keyhash.  This is one of the reasons
Cyclone DDS doesn't touch the keyhash if it can at all avoid it.

This commit adds a test that takes a well-known collision and verifies
that the instance handles are unique and that the key hash has the
expected value.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Fix test sensitive to byte-order in internal key

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Always store key in ddsi_serdata_default

This firstly fixes the bug where a key that results in a MD5 hash
collision would cause what should be two instances to be presented as if
it were only one.

Secondly, for XTypes something needs to be done to deal with different
data representations, because CDR/XCDR1 has all primitive types aligned
to a multiple of their size, but XCDR2 has the maximum alignment set to
4, so that padding before 64-bit integers and floating-point numbers may
be different.

Having the ability to store a copy of the key in a standard format means
we can deal with that while still being able to implement the global key
value to instance-handle mapping, &c.

The payload is always in native endianness, so this is also changes the
key representation to be in native endianness, as that allows (at the
very least) an SDK_KEY serdata to have only a single copy of the value.

This means that the DDSI keyhash generation gets more expensive on
little-endian machines, but that thing is of rather limited value and
avoided at all cost by Cyclone anyway.  Besides, see above about MD5:
when that thing isn't next-to-useless, it is outright dangerous.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Dennis Potman
data.message:
XCDR2 support for idlc and cdrstream serializer

This commit adds support for XCDR2 as defined in the DDS XTypes specification, and prepares
the IDL compiler (C backend) and the cdrstream serializer to be able to handle the idl
descriptions of types used in the DDS XTypes specification.

- Adds the implementation of the Data Representation QoS policy (XTypes spec section 7.6.3.1),
  which allows to set the CDR1 or XCDR2 data representation on a topic, reader or writer.
  Based on the extensibility of the data, the encoding will be chosen (plain, delimited
  or parameter-list CDR).

- Enhancements in the cdrstream serializer, so that it supports XCDR2 and recursive
  types and can be used to (de)serialize the types used in the XTypes type system.
    - XCDR2 support, which includes the encodings
        PLAIN_CDR2: types with extensibility final (slightly different from PLAIN_CDR v1,
        as described in XTypes spec section 7.4.2)
        DELIMITED_CDR: appendable types
        PL_CDR2: for aggregated types with extensibility mutable
    - Support for bounded strings stored as a pointer (serializer VM instruction BSP)
    - Add checking if a value for an enumerated type is in the valid range
      (currently only a check for maximum value)
    - Support recursive types, the serializer VM has a new type instruction EXT,
      to indicate that the instructions for a type are outside the current block
      (this can be either a forward or backward jump). All nested structs (also
      non-recursive ones) will be using the EXT instruction, so this also changes
      the processing of keys in nested types (which is using a new instruction `DDS_OP_KOF`
      for the key offsets).
    - The JEQ instruction, currently used for union type cases, is now also used for
      instruction offset for member of aggregated mutable types.
    - New VM instructions introduced for appendable (DDS_OP_DLC) and mutable types (DDS_OP_PLC)
    - Support is added for external data, as defined in the XTypes specification
      section 7.3.1.2.1.4 (the serializer flag DDS_OP_FLAG_EXT)
    - A new set of tests, mainly focussed on testing the features that are introduced
      in this commit.
    - For calculation of the type identifier hashes in the XTypes type system,
      litte-endian serialization shall be used for serializing type objects. This commit
      adds support to the cdrstream serializer for writing CDR in LE format, in addition
      to the existing write functions that are using native endianness.

- Changes in the idl compiler front-end and C backend, to support all idl language
  features that are used in the XTypes idl descriptions of type object, type identifiers,
  and type lookup service request and response types.
    - Add support for forward declarations for structs and union types, to support
      recursive types.
    - Add support for the bitmask type (note that the same version of this code is also
      included in an earlier PR)
    - Support external data (see below for more details
    - @id annotation support (e.g. used for appendable and mutable types)
    - prevent empty structs in output types (because the C99 spec and MSVC don't allow it)
    - Add support for @extensibility, @final, @appendable, @mutable annotations, and
      generate the serialization VM instruction according to a type's extensibility.
    - Add support for bounded strings as pointers, enum maximum value,
      the EXT type instruction, the key offset list (DDS_OP_KOF)

Some features are missing or not fully implemented in this commit. This list below
lists some of these, and also includes some known-issues in this implementation:
- The must-understand annotation is not fully implemented
- Explicit default values are not supported
- IDLC should check if a key member is 'must-understand' and non-optional
- Built-in member annotations (min, max, unit) are not supported
- Verbatim annotations are not supported
- The EMHEADER length code could be optimized for certain types (use 5-7 instead of 4,
  see XTypes spec section 7.4.3.4.2)
- Optimize for reading PL_XCDR2 members sequentially
- Test cases should be added for interoperability with CDR1 nodes
- Remove some code duplication in cdrstream (e.g. extract key functions)
- Implement idl_case_label_intvalue for non-integer types (enum, char, octet, bool)

Signed-off-by: Dennis Potman <dennis.potman@adlinktech.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Windows stack: also print module-relative address

It turns out that if no PDB file is available, SymFromAddr returns a
symbol + displacement that I can't figure out how to translate back to
the function in "cdb" when I do have the PDB file.

This commit makes sure to always print the module base address and
relative address.  If the PDB file is available, the output of
SymFromAddr is easier to use, but otherwise the module-relative
displacements are sufficient to recover the information offline.

For example:
```
  1633445360.924150 [0]  threadmon: C:\dev\cyclonedds\vsbuild\bin\RelWithDebInfo\ddsc.dll@0x7ff8cff00000!0xab013 ddsi_sertopic_serdata_from_ser_iov+0xa7cff
  1633445360.924258 [0]  threadmon: C:\dev\cyclonedds\vsbuild\bin\RelWithDebInfo\ddsc.dll@0x7ff8cff00000!0xab061 ddsi_sertopic_serdata_from_ser_iov+0xa7d4d
  1633445360.924364 [0]  threadmon: C:\dev\cyclonedds\vsbuild\bin\RelWithDebInfo\ddsc.dll@0x7ff8cff00000!0x964bc ddsi_sertopic_serdata_from_ser_iov+0x931a8
  1633445360.924471 [0]  threadmon: C:\dev\cyclonedds\vsbuild\bin\RelWithDebInfo\ddsc.dll@0x7ff8cff00000!0x96326 ddsi_sertopic_serdata_from_ser_iov+0x93012
```
followed by `cdb ddsperf.exe` and:
```
  0:000> .lines
  Line number information will be loaded
  0:000> .sympath bin\RelWithDebInfo\abc
  Symbol search path is: bin\RelWithDebInfo\abc
  0:000> ln ddsc+0xab013
  C:\dev\cyclonedds\src\ddsrt\src\sync\windows\sync.c(64)+0xf
  (00007ff8`cfe0b000)   ddsc!ddsrt_cond_wait+0x13   |  (00007ff8`cfe0b030)   ddsc!ddsrt_cond_waitfor
  0:000> ln ddsc+0xab061
  C:\dev\cyclonedds\src\ddsrt\src\sync\windows\sync.c(116)
  (00007ff8`cfe0b030)   ddsc!ddsrt_cond_waitfor+0x31   |  (00007ff8`cfe0b100)   ddsc!ddsrt_cond_waituntil
  0:000> ln ddsc+0x964bc
  C:\dev\cyclonedds\src\core\ddsc\src\dds_waitset.c(82)+0x16
  (00007ff8`cfdf6360)   ddsc!dds_waitset_wait_impl+0x15c   |  (00007ff8`cfdf65b0)   ddsc!dds_waitset_wait_until
  0:000> ln ddsc+0x96326
  C:\dev\cyclonedds\src\core\ddsc\src\dds_waitset.c(395)
  (00007ff8`cfdf62d0)   ddsc!dds_waitset_wait+0x56   |  (00007ff8`cfdf6360)   ddsc!dds_waitset_wait_impl
```
Which is the correct stack trace.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Robin Lindén
data.message:
Fix use of non-existent paths when building as a subproject

CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR always points to the top-level CMake project, so if
CycloneDDS was included as a gitmodule or pulled in using CMake
FetchContent, the CMake step would fail with errors like

```
CMake Error at cyclonedds/src/tools/idlc/CMakeLists.txt:52 (file):
file failed to open for reading (No such file or directory):
/home/robin/dds-project/src/ddsrt/include/getopt.h.in

CMake Error: File /home/robin/dds-project/src/ddsrt/src/getopt.c does not exist.
CMake Error at cyclonedds/src/tools/idlc/CMakeLists.txt:61 (configure_file):
configure_file Problem configuring file

CMake Error at cyclonedds/src/tools/idlc/CMakeLists.txt:95 (include):
include could not find load file:
/home/robin/dds-project/cmake/Modules/Generate.cmake
```

This commit replaces CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR with <PROJECT_NAME>_SOURCE_DIR, a
variable that always points to the source dir of the named project.

See:
https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.21/variable/CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR.html
https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.21/variable/PROJECT-NAME_SOURCE_DIR.html

Signed-off-by: Robin Lindén <_@robinlinden.eu>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Handle too deeply nested XML configs

There is a maximum nesting depth for the configuration that is
determined by the internal configuration tables.  Simply aborting the
interpretation of the XML input on the first unrecognized element item
would guarantee never exceeding the maximum nesting depth.  As an error
handling strategy this is less user-friendly than ignoring some of the
input, attempting to interpret the remainder and reporting any further
issues.

This commit makes it abort the interpretation as soon as the maximum
nesting depth is reached, in all other cases it continues and reports as
many issues with the configuration as it can.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

  works aruond that by storing a more meaningful return value in the
  parser state object;

* the token name table generated by %token-table is deprecated and has
  been for quite some time, and it seems that now the accompanying
  mapping to internal token numbers is gone as well, this uses a hack to
  work around that.

solution for the failing CI runs on macOS.

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Lock ddsi writer when inspecting its address set

Not holding that lock is definitely a race condition.  This change was
triggered by an abort in ddsc_data_avail_stress_remote:

Thread 15 Crashed:: writer
libsystem_kernel.dylib  __pthread_kill
libsystem_pthread.dylib pthread_kill
libsystem_c.dylib       abort
libddsc.0.8.0.dylib     ddsrt_mutex_lock (sync.c:42)
libddsc.0.8.0.dylib     addrset_empty (q_addrset.c:484)
libddsc.0.8.0.dylib     dds_write_impl (dds_write.c:525)
libddsc.0.8.0.dylib     dds_write (dds_write.c:196)
cunit_ddsc              writethread (data_avail_stress.c:37)

The abort is because pthread_mutex_lock failed, that almost certainly
means it is no longer a valid mutex.  One way that might happen is if
the addrset is being freed (which calls pthread_mutex_destroy).  There
is a short window between destroying the mutex and freeing the memory,
so this scenario is possible even with the address saniziter enabled.

It does require that the rebuild_writer_addrset was called at roughly
the same time, that in turn requires there to be discovery activity.
The nature of the test means this is likely, and there is even still
evidence of ongoing discovery processing in the stack traces:

Thread 2:: dq.builtins
libddsc.0.8.0.dylib     conode_from_node (avl.c:91)
libddsc.0.8.0.dylib     ddsrt_avl_lookup_succ (avl.c:813)
libddsc.0.8.0.dylib     ddsrt_avl_lookup_succ (avl.c:813)
libddsc.0.8.0.dylib     entidx_enum_next (ddsi_entity_index.c:504)
libddsc.0.8.0.dylib     entidx_enum_next_max (ddsi_entity_index.c:514)
libddsc.0.8.0.dylib     generic_do_match (q_entity.c:3074)
libddsc.0.8.0.dylib     match_proxy_reader_with_writers (q_entity.c:3133)
libddsc.0.8.0.dylib     new_proxy_reader (q_entity.c:6464)
libddsc.0.8.0.dylib     handle_sedp_alive_endpoint (q_ddsi_discovery.c:1712)
libddsc.0.8.0.dylib     handle_sedp (q_ddsi_discovery.c:1838)
libddsc.0.8.0.dylib     builtins_dqueue_handler (q_ddsi_discovery.c:2076)
libddsc.0.8.0.dylib     dqueue_thread (q_radmin.c:2552)

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Add example for using built-in topics

This adds an example of using the built-in topics by monitoring
DCPSTopic for 10s.  Whether or not DCPSTopic is available is determined
by the ENABLE_TOPIC_DISCOVERY build-time flag, and the code checks for
the case where that is disabled.

Whether DCPSTopic behaves like one expects is further governed by the
Discovery/EnableTopicDiscoveryEndpoints setting.  If it is disabled,
there is no topic discovery over the network and this program would not
really show any topics.

Because of that, it also monitors DCPSPublication and DCPSSubscription
and prints a warning if some endpoints are discovered when no topics are
discovered.  That check is simple enough and has the added benefit of
also introducing these two topics in the sample example.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Remove Visual Studio analyzer from builds

The analyzer doesn't do a good job if there are no SAL2 annotations, but
those annotations are only supported by Visual Studio, the documentation
is very incomplete and it is (nearly) impossible to get them right
without actually compiling the code with Visual Studio.  The latter is
what it makes it really impossible to use them.

That makes dealing with false positives from the Visual Studio analzyer
far more trouble than it is worth (especially considering we're also
using the clang and gcc analyzers and Coverity).

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Add test for combination of waitset and listener

This adds a test to verify that invoking a DATA_AVAILABLE listener
configured not to auto-reset the status does indeed allow a waitset to
trigger and that the waitset (generally, there is a short window in time
during which the status can be observed) wakes up after the listener was
invoked.

It tests this both in the case of a listener that doesn't reset
DATA_AVAILABLE internally, and in the case of a listener that does reset
it by calling dds_take().

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Status mask should only affect waitset triggering

This brings the behaviour of the status mask in line with the
specification, previously masking an event (i.e., clearing its bit in
the mask) would have two additional, impractical consequences:

* It would prevent a listener from being invoked.  If there is no need
  for a listener, don't set one.

* It would force the corresponding status to 0 (not signalled), making
  it impossible to poll for events outside the status mask.  E.g., with
  a waitset and a mask of DATA_AVAILABLE to wait for the arrival of
  data, it was impossible to observe any liveliness changed events on
  the same reader.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Leave status set on invoking listener if requested

This provides the implementation of leaving the status flags set in the
entity when invoking a listener if that listener was set with the
"invoke_on_reset" flag clear (via the new, extended interface for
setting listeners), and resetting it as required by the spec otherwise.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Add _arg version for listener setters/getters

These extend on the existing setters/getters as follows:

* Provide a return value for returning BAD_PARAMETER if the "listener"
  argument is a null pointer.

* Allow overriding the listener argument pointer specified in the
  dds_create_listener call.  This is quite useful but the workaround for
  the absence of this argument was a rather convoluted procedure
  combining getting, setting and merging listeners.

* A new boolean argument whether (true) or not (false) the status
  corresponding to the listener should be reset prior to invoking the
  listener (or more precisely: never get set) as described in the DDS
  specification.  Setting it to false allows installing listeners
  without side-effects.

The old functions have been re-written in terms of the extended ones.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Only materialize DATA_ON_READERS when needed

The vast majority of the DDS applications ignores DATA_ON_READERS, as it
really is only useful for group ordered/coherent subscribers, and those
weren't available in any DDS implementation for many years.  Cyclone
doesn't have them either.

At the same time, DATA_ON_READERS is relatively costly, because the spec
says it should always be raised when DATA_AVAILABLE is on any of the
subscriber's readers, and reset when read/take is called on any of the
same.  That roughly means every single time a reader history cache is
updated, the subscriber status has to be manipulated as well.

It turns out that this has a significant performance impact once one
allows the statuses to remain set even when invoking the listener, so
that one can have listeners that monitor without any side-effects.
(Significant here is 3.02MS/s -> 2.95MS/s in ddsperf -TOU pub/sub test
on my laptop, and the significane is perhaps more in sinking below 3MS/s
than in any absolute terms!)

This commit addresses that be only materializing the DATA_ON_READERS
state when the subscriber is attached to a waitset, and returning an
approximation of it when querying the subscriber's status.  The
workaround for getting a materialized DATA_ON_READERS is to create an
otherwise unused waitset with just the subscriber attached to it.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
PoC: Set statuses prior to invoking listener

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Allow mask = 0 for read/take status operation

The documentation comment suggests it is allowed, though it said "NULL"
and didn't say what exactly that means, but in any case 0 was a rather
useless value as it would turn the operation into a no-op.

The wisdom of returning an error if the mask contains status flags not
relevant to the particular entity type is also doubtful, but if 0 is
allowed to simply mean "everything", that is not really much of an
issue.

And with that change, dds_get_status_changes becomes an alias for
dds_read_status with mask = 0.  Deprecating should be considered, as the
"get" is rather ambiguous and can just as easily be interpreted as an
innocent "getter" or as a function that also reset the status.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

There was a double-allocation and addition of an null-initialised
"ignored partition" each time an "ignored partition" was given in the
configuration.  Fortunately, the way the configuration printing, freeing
and matching code handled this meant that it did no real harm.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

and was erroneously included in the separators.  This hasn't been
released yet so it can still be fixed without worrying about complicated
work-arounds.

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Make actual built-in topic entities inaccessible

Built-in topics are identified using compile-time constants, but
creating readers for these does cause just-in-time instantiation of
proper topic entities.  This commits hides them from the application by
returning the corresponding pseudo-handle from dds_get_topic and
skipping them in dds_get_children.

Still, the application could determine the handle by invoking
dds_get_name on all handles and looking for, e.g., DCPSParticipant.
This commit therefore furthermore blocks access to these entities.  This
ensures that the application can't do any QoS changes, define listeners,
or whatever.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Chris Lalancette
data.message:
Increase the CRL expiration date.

When I wrote the tests for CRL, I forgot that I used the
"recommended" practice of 30 days for the CRL.  Since that
has now expired, some of the CRL tests are failing.

Instead, increase the CRL time up to 73000 days, which makes
it valid for 200 years.  This isn't recommended best practice
for a real deployment, but should keep the tests from ever
failing in this way again.

I also had to regenerate the CRL when doing this and update
the tests to use that CRL file.

Signed-off-by: Chris Lalancette <clalancette@openrobotics.org>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Give up when fopen fails (CID 329674, 329677)

When fopen() failed on an include file because of reaching the maximum
number of open files, the mcpp preprocessor tried to save the day by
closing a file and reopening it later.  It did that without error
handling, but the file may no longer exist or the fseek() may fail.

Secondly, the case of an include with a null pointer for the FILE object
is considered a case where the file name is obtained by expanding a
macro, and in the error handling that macro is assumed to exist.
Consequently, there is no simple representation available that would
avoid a crash.

Rather than adding one, just give up when fopen fails.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Fix assert on expr return type (CID 329693)

The type should be exactly one of four types, which the original bit
manipulation got right as it is exactly the types for which

  (t & IDL_LONG) == IDL_LONG

However, the asserts have other terms that are either wrong or
superfluous and trigger a warning from Coverity.  This changes the
assert to list the acceptable types explicitly.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Yield 0 for undefined bit shifts (CID 329652)

Shifting by at least the width of the left operand results undefined
behaviour, and Coverity rightly warns about the possibility of invalid
shift counts in the preprocessor expression evaluation.  As it is
undefined behaviour, it is also allowed to check and yield 0.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

A failure to create a new cipher context using EVP_CIPHER_CTX_new would
result in calling EVP_DecryptInit_ex with a null context in the test

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Set "exponent" state parsing floats (CID 329669)

The code parsing a floating-point number didn't change to the (already
defined) "exponent" state upon encountering one, with the result that
"1e1e1" would be treated as a single floating-point number and resulting
in an assertion later because strtod would disagree.

Accepting a "truncated exponent", e.g., "1.1e" or "1.1e-" as a valid
floating-point literal rather strange, but the CORBA spec version 3.1.1,
section 7.2.5.3 does seem to say that.  So with this fix, this is
presumably ok.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Ignore idl_asprintf return (CID 329659, 329666)

idl_asprintf doesn't touch the output parameter on error, so if the
output is initialized to a null pointer and there is a check for a null
pointer afterward, the return value is not relevant.

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Eliminate false OOBR warning (CID 332211)

key_size is actually always 32 and EVP_MAX_MD_SIZE is 64, so there is no
problem, but Coverity quite reasonably says that asserting key_size <=
INT32_MAX implies it may be larger than 64.  That assert was to protect
the cast-to-int.

Adding a compile time check that EVP_MAX_MD_SIZE fits in an int and a
run-time one that key_size is no larger than EVP_MAX_MD_SIZE should do
the trick.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Fix uninit memory warning (CID 332212, 332213)

Looks like a false positive from Coverity, but a memset with a bit
pattern that won't pass any of the checks allows eliminating the warning
while maintaining reasonable certainty that the tests will pick up a
missing (or partial) initialization.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Fix memory leak (CID 332214)

Introduced in 522533c27fbe79d372f1fd0f3676599f34359320; the "address
set" changed bailout is used only when a remote reader's address changes
while it is computing the writer address set.  This is a rather unusual
event (and currently never occurs if the peer is also Cyclone DDS).

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Fix incorrect alloc size (CID 332215)

Introduced in 52e0e9bf16093527fe7e01120cb6321ce94b7efe;
locator-to-string is only ever called with a buffer that is larger than
8 bytes, so the damage is only in outputting an invalid locator string
on a 32-bits platform.  That in itself should not be a major problem.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Fix incorrect alloc size (CID 332216)

because in that case, it actually allocated a little bit more than
needed.

Fix submission to Coverity Scan

platform was prefixed with SCAN_BUILD too, discarding the results of

around no compilation units are captured and no files emitted causing
Coverity Scan to report a build error.

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Advertise addresses independent of ManySocketsMode

ManySocketsMode controls whether or not each participant has its own
socket and, therefore, unique port number.  The code published the
correct set of address/ports when all participants shared a set of
sockets (the default mode), but published just one address if each
participant has its own sockets/ports.

Moreover, if an external address is configured the address published in
the latter case was the wrong one since
da75c2fd188c4fa19b07e91185d9fb23bfd84c5e.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Clarify initialization of external address

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Always use actual interface address for same host

In a containerized environment, the process inside the
container (sometimes) need to advertise an address different from what
the configured address is, but cannot communicate with other processes
within the container using that external address.

This rewrites a discovered address that matches a configured external
address with the interface's actual address.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Recognize locators matching an external address

When a configuration specifies an external address X and a discovery
message is received that advertises address X, it makes sense to treat
it as the same machine, which then also allows loopback addresses to be
considered.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Replace global with per-interface external address

The ExternalNetworkAddress setting really should control a per-interface
setting, not a single global one.  This moves the configured external
address to the interface array and changes the configuration processing
to accept an external network address setting if there is a unique
non-loopback interface, rather than just a single interface.  It leaves
everything else the same.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Transmit: skip size check if no limit set

If there is no need to store the sample in the WHC or transmit it, this
is the only place where the transmit path checks the size of a sample.
Skipping the size check if the size is set to unlimited (INT32_MAX is
the default value and is taken to mean unlimited) means that there is no
longer a need to serialize a sample that is transferred only via
Iceoryx.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Add a test of various Iceoryx use cases to the CI

The test emulates two processes on host A and two on host B, then
creates a writer in one "process" and variety of readers sprinkled
throughout all the others.  It then checks that a [write, dispose,
write, unregister] sequence shows up correctly in all the readers that
should get it.  It also verifies that the calculated address sets match
the expectation.

Emulating multiple processes is done in the usual fashion, by
instantiating the same domain multiple times.  Emulating two hosts is
relevant only to Iceoryx and is done by overriding the locator and
service names.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Iceoryx check on endpoint instead of participant

Since 90ee3642576b4c115e0eb9c0fcbd83a097364d40 the iceoryx locator is no
longer included in the participant discovery data, and hence the flag on
the proxy participant has been false since.  This means the data is
erroneously no longer treated as acknowledged.

This commit moves the "is_iceoryx" from the proxy participant to the proxy
reader/writer entities and removes the reference to the proxy
participant's flag to that of the proxy reader.

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Multi-homing support + redundant networking

This will (probably) fail if:

* you enable General/RedundantNetworking with more than 3 interfaces per
  reader (on average in the system) (hard-coded multiplier instead of
  counting properly);

* you try to enable TCP or source-specific multicast;

* you include interfaces with link-local IPv6 addresses other
  non-routed/local interfaces among the advertised addresses that aren't
  recognised as such;

* you have interface aliases within the same subnet (I haven't
  considered how it would blow up, but I think it won't like it);

* you have more than 250 reader-interfaces with
  General/RedundantNetworking (hard-coded upper limit on reader "names"
  for making sense of debugging output);

* you advertise multicast addresses that are not listened on by all
  multicast-capable networks, and/or if there's disagreement between
  machines on whether an interface is multicast-capable;

* (possibly something else I can't think of right now)

Some of these bugs disappear if you use only a single interface, but
some details in the behaviour do change compared to the "normal"
version.

But otherwise:

* General/NetworkInterfaceAddress = lo0,en0,en1

  Will make it use these three interfaces while trying to minimize the
  number of packets sent to reach all destinations.  Without specifying
  loopback explicitly it will rely on the kernel routing the packets
  over loopback for local readers (like it has always done).

  Specifying it means it will use it and advertise it to the others, how
  other implementations respond to that, I don't know.

* General/RedundantNetworking = true

  Will make it advertise in a vendor-specific setting that it would like
  to receive data on all advertised interfaces simultaneously, rather
  than on one.

Multi-network support is important, so this is definitely not a wasted
effort; and although it won't be obvious from the current state of
things it'll actually result in a cleaning-up of code.

As far as redundant networking goes, I'm not sure the additional
complexity is worth it compared to the simple one where the transport
simply sends it out twice with a small address transformation in
between.  What this allows (although I haven't made it configurable) is
to make it dependent on the individual readers.  Whether that's valuable
... let's say I have my doubts.

Another downside is that this relies on a discovery protocol extension
and so isn't interoperable with other implementations, whereas always
sending on two wires is interoperable.

Finally, load-balancing would be a useful feature to have as well and
while that is perfectly straightforward when done at the transport level
it is not quite so trivial at this level.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

can be found is better done on stdout.

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Consistently consume the Iceoryx chunk in writecdr

If there are no Iceoryx subscribers, the chunk must still be returned to
Iceoryx.  The cost of preparing the chunk is low enough to always
publish the chunk, rather than checking whether subscribers exist and
dropping it if there are none.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Delay publishing via Iceoryx in writecdr

Publishing a chunk via Iceoryx means the shared memory chunk can no
longer be used by the publisher.  Therefore, if remote subscribers
exist, the serialization must be done prior to publishing via Iceoryx.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Perform local delivery via Iceoryx

Readers/writers that use Iceoryx cause data to be delivered via Iceoryx
and this is important to get the refcounting of shared memory chunks
correct.  This suppresses the local delivery path to avoid delivering
the data twice.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Martijn Reicher
data.message:
Added QoS compatibility checks for Shared Memory

Checks are now done on the following QoS settings
before shared memory transfer is enabled:
- liveliness set to automatic
- deadline set to infinite
- reliability set to reliable
- durability set to volatile
- history set to keep last
  - writer history depth no larger than the iox publisher
    history capacity
  - reader history depth no larger than the iox subscriber
    history request

Signed-off-by: Martijn Reicher <martijn.reicher@adlinktech.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Add secure configs to perftest script

This adds two options to the perftest script:

* security mode, which is either:

  - "none" (the default) for running without any security features
    enabled;

  - "sign" for running with RTPS message signing

  - "encrypt" for running with payload encryption

  - one of a number of other settings

  - a governance XML file to control the settings in more detail if
    desired

* rate-limited operation: many seem to like to measure the latency at a
  fixed message rate, and this option makes it possible to use this
  script for such measurements.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Add latency info to ddsperf "sub" mode

When run in a network with well-synchronized clocks (or over a loopback
interface), one-way latency can be determined directly.  This adds an
option to do so in the subscriber mode.  The latency of small samples at
unlimited rate will be higher than that of somewhat larger samples as a
consequence of batching them.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Test participant instance handle with security

DDS Security requires rewriting participant GUIDs, which interferes a
bit with the mapping to instance handles in the built-in topics.  This
adds a test to verify that the instance handle and GUID line up.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Remap GUID to iid after adjustment by security

The DDS security specification requires a transformation to be applied
to the GUID but that happens after the common code already mapped the
GUID to an instance id.  With this commit, the original mapping is
replaced by one for the new GUID.

It is a very inelegant solution, but some with the work for delayed
enabling of entities being underway and requiring changes to the time at
which GUIDs and these instance ids get assigned, it makes sense to do a
minimally invasive change now.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Add abstraction for reader/writer-specific alloc

This adds a pair of functions to initialize/finalize a "data_allocator"
object that can be used to do memory allocations bound to a reader or a
writer:

* dds_data_allocator_init
* dds_data_allocator_fini

as well as a pair of functions to perform an allocation or free memory:

* dds_data_allocator_alloc
* dds_data_allocator_free

For readers/writers that use Iceoryx, these map to the Iceoryx shared
memory operations.  For all other cases, they are simply aliases for
ddsrt_malloc and ddsrt_free.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Add flag for indicating fixed size types

Knowing whether all instances of a type have the same size is useful
information, for example for deciding whether or not to route data via
Iceoryx.  The sertype implementation remains responsible for the actual
allocation, and so there is no direct need to extend the interface with
a function that returns the size of a sample.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Give serdata_from_ser access to the keyhash

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>

data.author: Erik Boasson
data.message:
Allow a sertype to request keyhashes in messages

This commit adds a vendor-specific parameter to the discovery parameters
that allows a reader to request the writers generate a "keyhash", also
implementing the mechanics of letting a sertype determine whether this
is set, tracking the number of proxy readers requesting it in a writer,
and generating the keyhash if at least one reader requests it (or if the
old global override is set, or if DDS security requires it be
generated).

Making the keyhash (if included) available to serdata_from_ser is the
subject of another commit (arguably an independent one, as the keyhash
may be available also if not requested).

There exist *some* legitimate cases of using a keyhash and that is the
reason this is added.  Anyone contemplating using them should take some
specification mishaps into consideration:

The keyhash is a 16-byte blob, constructed either as:

* the big-endian serialization of the key fields, with padding zeroed
  out and any unneeded bytes also set to zero (the order is presumably
  that in which the fields occur in the serialization of the sample;
  and there is presumably padding within the keyhash to maintain CDR
  alignment, but the spec is not perfectly clear on this); or

* the MD5 hash of the serialized form, if the serialized form cannot be
  guaranteed to be at most 16 bytes long (i.e., a key consisting of just
  a bounded string of at most 11 characters is always at most 16 bytes;
  a key consisting of an unbounded string may be longer).

The idea is that this allows a more efficient way of identifying the
instances in the reader, and (as per the DDS Security spec, 7.1.1.4) to
allow infrastructures services to implement the DDS QoS (notably
history) without knowing the type or being able to decrypt the data.
Problems are plentiful, with some obvious ones:

* The first and obvious problem for using the keyhash to identify
  instances is that there can be hash collisions once MD5 gets used;

* The quality of the keyhash if it is not the MD5 hash of the serialized
  key is abominable as a hash, necessitating further hashing on the
  reader side and neutering the potential performance advantage;

* The need to serialize the key fields twice;

for which reasons Cyclone DDS originally tried to avoid generating or
using the keyhash.  With the addition of DDS Security and DDS XTypes,
some additional issues are introduced:

* The Security spec mandates that the keyhash it is *always* in "MD5
  form" when keys are to be protected. However, it is possible for a
  reader to match both secured and non-secured writers, and in such a
  case, for topics where the keyhash ordinarily is *not* MD5, the same
  instance will be identified by different key hashes for the two
  writers;

* XTypes' notion of assignability allows different matching writers to
  have different forms of keyhashes (plain/MD5) and to have differently
  sized keys that result in a different serialization.  E.g.:

    string<10> is-assignable-to string

  and can cause the plain/MD5 confusion, and

    short is-assignable-to int

  and so a writer for {int;int} and one for {short;short} both yield
  "plain" keyhashes that are different, yet describe the same instance,
  and if the first writes {0x0101,0} and the latter writes {0x01,0x01}
  there are different instances mapping to the same keyhash.

With XTypes, the type information is available, so these cases can be
detected.  Matching both protected and unprotected writers can also be
detected, and so in those cases the keyhash needs to be ignored.  This
is not yet implemented.

In short:

* Generating keyhashes is up to the writer, and this is a Cyclone
  specific extension.

* Keyhashes cannot safely be used as proxies for key values.  At best
  one can detect problematic cases and refuse to make the keyhash
  available even when it is present in the message.

And so this feature should not be relied on except in well-controlled
environments.

Signed-off-by: Erik Boasson <eb@ilities.com>
